text:
While awards for architecture are granted by various institutions and civic organizations, the most cherished are those conferred by the professional organizations of architects since these signify peer recognition. The oldest of these is the Gold Medal of Merit (GMM) awarded by the Philippine Institute of Architects to architects who have achieved excellence during the course of their careers. The GMM awardees include Andres Luna de San Pedro in 1949; Juan F. Nakpil in 1951; Fernando H. Ocampo in 1953; Tomas Mapua in 1954; Juan M. Arellano in 1958; Antonio M. Toledo in 1961; Cesar H. Concio in 1964; Carlos E. da Silva in 1973; Jose Ma. Zaragoza in 1977; Leandro V. Locsin in 1978; Carlos Arguelles in 1988; Antonio S. Sindiong in 1989; Carlos A. Santos-Viola in 1990; Cristobal B. C. Espina in 1991; Rogelio G. Villarosa in 1997; William V. Coscolluela in 1997; and Paulino T. Lim in 1998.

The highest award granted by the United Architects of the Philippines (UAP) is the Likha Award and Gold Medal. The UAP By-Laws, Article III, Section 5, describes the award as “the highest distinction that may be bestowed by the National Board upon a Fellow of the United Architects of the Philippines... [t]his award shall be given as a recognition of his having achieved the highest standard of ethical conduct and excellence in the practice and service of the architectural profession and for his distinguished contribution and service to the UAP organization and to his community, his government and country.” In the UAP’s more than two decades of existence, the Likha Award has been conferred only on five architects: Felipe M. Mendoza in 1982; Leandro V. Locsin in 1987; Gabriel P. Formoso in 1990; Cesar V. Canchela in 1995; and Manuel T. Mañosa Jr in 1995.

 

The Professional Regulations Commission also confers awards on outstanding architects. Awardees include Otilio A. Arellano in 1977; Leandro V. Locsin in 1978; Gabriel P. Formoso in 1979; Antonio V. Ascalon in 1980; Manuel T. Mañosa Jr in 1981; Felipe M. Mendoza in 1982; Gregorio G. Segura in 1983; Jose J. Herrera in 1984 (posthumously); Fernando B. Abad in 1985; Cesar V. Canchela in 1988; Geronimo V. Manahan in 1989; Norberta M. Nuke in 1990; Aquiles C. Paredes in 1991; Froilan L. Hong in 1992; Ruperto C. Gaite in 1993; Francisco T. Mañosa in 1994; Gabino A. De Leon in 1995; Antonio A. Turalba in 1996; Jaime C. Marquez in 1997; and Philip H. Recto in 1998.

The Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan Awards, instituted in 1963 by the Office of the Mayor of the City of Manila, are conferred every year on 24 Jun as part of the Araw ng Maynila celebration. The awardees for architecture include: Fernando H. Ocampo in 1964; Tomas Mapua in 1964; Andres Luna de San Pedro in 1964; Arcadio Arellano in 1966; Juan M. Arellano in 1967; Juan F. Nakpil in 1968; Cesar H. Concio in 1969; Otilio A. Arellano in 1970; Pablo S. Antonio in 1971; Gabino A. de Leon in 1971; Leandro V. Locsin in 1972; lldefonso P. Santos in 1972; Jose Ma. Zaragoza in 1973; Angel E. Nakpil in 1974; Carlos E. da Silva in 1975; Felipe M. Mendoza in 1976; Gabriel P. Formoso in 1977; Manuel T. Mañosa Jr in 1978; Ruperto C. Gaite in 1979; Jesus M. Bondoc in 1980; Carlos A. Santos-Viola in 1981; Francisco T. Mañosa in 1982; Jorge Ramos in 1983; Francis L. Arcenas in 1984; Ruben L. Mariano in 1984; Engracio L. Mariano in 1985; Francisco B. Fajardo in 1985; Carlos D. Arguelles in 1988; Antonio S. Sindiong in 1989; Ramon Faustmann in 1991; Cesar V. Canchela in 1992; Felino Palafox Jr. in 2001; and Alfred Geoffrey Carandang in 2015.

The Republic Cultural Heritage Awards in Architecture awardees are Carlos Arguelles in 1968; Leandro V. Locsin in 1970; Samahang Nakpil, Nakpil, Nakpil at Nakpil in 1971; Pablo S. Antonio in 1972; and Gabriel Formoso in 1973.

 

The National Artist Award is considered the highest honor for an architect and for any artist. This award is conferred by the Philippine government through the Cultural Center of the Philippines and the National Commission for Culture and the Arts. The National Artist Awards were instituted in 1972, and since then five architects have received it: Juan F. Nakpil in 1973; Pablo S. Antonio in 1976; Leandro V. Locsin in 1990; Ildefonso Santos in 2006; and Jose Maria V. Zaragoza in 2014.  Written by René B. Javellana

Sections

Structural Forms
The Indigenous Tradition
The Hispanic Colonial Tradition
The American Colonial Tradition

After architectural designs are made or decided upon, the process of construction begins. In this process, materials are prepared, formed, and assembled in various ways or methods to create habitable structures.

Structural Forms

A building consists of space and structure. The form of space is defined by the structure that encloses it. The extent of space covered by the structure is determined by the strength of its materials or by the manner in which such materials are put together. There are several forms or systems of construction. Post-and-lintel construction consists of a horizontal member, called lintel or beam, supported at both ends by vertical members, called posts or columns. On the horizontal member rests a load consisting of a section of a wall, floor, or roof. Indigenous houses, like the bahay kubo, and stone and wooden buildings, like the bahay na bato, employ this type of construction. Greek temples made of marble were built using this form. This basic pattern is followed in the steel skeletons for high-rise buildings.

An arch is a curved structure used to span openings or to support a wall or roof. The arch was developed by ancient builders, particularly the Romans, who, aware of the limited tensile strength of stone, nonetheless devised a way of using it to span considerable widths. The early form of arch consisted of wedge-shaped blocks, arranged in a curve, with their joints perpendicular to the curve. With such construction, the downward thrust of the weight was resolved into horizontal or diagonal pressures, enabling the builders to cover larger spans than did the post-and-lintel system. The Romans used arches for various structures such as large halls, bridges, and aqueducts. In the Philippines, the arch was introduced during the Spanish colonial period. It was used for openings, structural supports, arcades, and bridges.

A vault is a curved-stone structure covering a space. The vault developed from the arch, using the same principle of construction. A vault may be described as an arch extended along its depth. The simplest form of vault is the tunnel vault or barrel vault. The walls of Intramuros contain a number of vaults. While stone vaults were common features in European churches, very few Philippine churches use them because of the danger caused by earthquakes.

A dome is a vault of hemispherical shape. It may be visualized as an arch turned on its axis. The earliest domes were made of stone, following the principle of the arch. Modern domes are made of reinforced concrete or steel. The dome of the Chapel of the Holy Sacrifice at the University of the Philippines is a reinforced-concrete shell, only 24 cm thick.

A truss is a frame composed of horizontal, vertical, and diagonal members, used in the construction of roofs and bridges. Since the triangle is the most stable shape in construction, the various parts of a truss form an assemblage of triangles. The overall form of an ordinary roof truss is a triangle. A truss may also have the form of a wide curve like an arch.

A cantilever is a slab, beam, truss, or any structural member projecting beyond its support, whether it is a wall, column, or girder. Cantilevers are used for wide roof overhangs, canopies, and balconies. The use of cantilevers makes modern buildings more exciting in appearance since a structure supported on only one side gives the impression of being suspended or being afloat. Whereas traditional buildings solidly supported on all sides are awesome for their stability, modern buildings employing cantilevers suggest movement, particularly a horizontal thrust. Cantilevers serve a practical purpose since they provide covered space free from any obstruction on its open sides, allowing unimpeded movement. For this reason they are standard devices for entrances and waiting areas. The front of the Cultural Center of the Philippines main building is dominated by a huge cantilevered block sheltering the entrance.

A space frame is a three-dimensional structural framework in which all members are interconnected to maximize stability and to effect resistance to loads applied in any direction. While the members of a truss lie on one plane, comprising height and width, the members of a space frame function in terms of height, width, and depth. The steel skeleton of a multistory building is a type of space frame. However, the term is more properly applied to a construction consisting of two parallel grids connected by diagonal or zigzagging bars. Space frames can span widths of a hundred meters or more, and have been used in the construction of domes. Because of its light construction, the space frame is one of the most economical structures for covering wide expanses. With its active play of lines and pleasing design, it is regarded as a work of technological art and can therefore be left exposed. Computer-aided design (CAD) rendering has contributed to the increasing use of space frames since the long, complex calculations, needed in their design, can now be rapidly accomplished.

 

The Indigenous Tradition

Indigenous architecture is based on a precise knowledge of the durability, strength, and possible use of materials found in the environment, like wood, leaves, rocks, and sometimes mud. As in most of Southeast Asia, the most common material is bamboo, which is used for beams, flooring, siding, and roofing. They may be used whole, split, flattened, or woven into sawali or amakan.

Building materials for ethnic houses include coconut wood and leaves; bakawan (mangrove); wood such as narra, pine, molave, for posts, beams and flooring; pawid or nipa, cogon grass, husk, and banana bark for sidings; and palm fronds, anahaw, and runo (cane grass) for roofing. The use of these materials may be seen in the Ifugao house, which has a roof of cogon, walls and floors of wooden planks, and four sturdy wooden posts that raise it above the ground. The Tausug bay sinug has a porch made of bamboo and built on bamboo posts and a living area resting on sturdy posts of wood. The kitchen, a separate structure connected by a bridge to the main house, is made of bamboo or wooden planks.

The Sama, whose houses are built on piles driven into the reef floor, use coconut wood, mangrove, or other trees for posts, and nipa and sawali for sidings and roofing. The daet-daet or lean-to of the Mamanua Negrito is an impromptu windscreen of leaves of wild banana, coconut fronds, or grass laid on a framework of twigs. The bahay kubo or nipa hut, the indigenous house of the lowland Filipino, utilizes its building materials with great skill. Split bamboo might be woven into pleasing chevron or diamond-shaped patterns. Regional variations in the use of material are evident. In the Tagalog region, sidings are generally of nipa while in the Visayas, these are made of bamboo: either split, flattened, or woven.

Indigenous houses are usually built with assistance from relatives and friends while the owner provides food and drink. This system of communal help is called bayanihan by lowland Filipinos. Master carpenters might be engaged for complex work that demands expertise and might be paid for their labor. Skills are passed on from generation to generation or from master to apprentice as among the carvers of the panolong, the decorative beam-end, found in the Maranao torogan (datu’s large house).

 

The Hispanic Colonial Tradition

The buildings during the 300 years of Spanish rule were so excellently shaped according to the materials and techniques available in the country that Rafael Diaz Arenas was moved to conclude in 1850 that “the Philippines has its own architecture.” The Spanish businessman says that the architects and engineers in the colony were able to appropriately address the various concerns about the climate and environment in their constructions, from the palaces of the various government and religious leaders, to private homes, and public structures. The house parts were so well linked with each other that they were considered earthquake resistant.

Haligi Construction. The first houses, churches, and buildings under Spanish rule hewed closely to indigenous design. A temporary shed would have a balangkas or framework with posts of bamboo. A thin wall (dingding, dindin, or bungbong) utilized light materials such as palm leaves or grass. A sheet of woven slats of bamboo for the wall or ceiling was known as sawali among the Tagalog, and amakan among the Visayans. Instead of nails, which were not used until much later, wooden pegs and dovetailed joints kept the pieces in place.

The Filipino anloagui (carpenter) was an expert at determining which wood was best suited for a particular function. For a sturdy housepost (adigi, haligi, or harigi), choices would range from palms like the anibung or sagisi, to the wood known as molave or mulawin which was distasteful to termites, hardened with age and did not rot although imbedded in the ground. As technology improved, these haligi were set into bases of lime and stone. Narra or naga (apalit among the Kapampangan) was a favorite for the tabla (floorboard), because of its deep red color and sheen when polished. Narra came in red and yellow; both types would be laid in alternation to give the floor more character.

Philippine forests yielded lumber known for its durability, sheen, color, and beauty. A basic list of trees useful for construction would include: acle or acli for buildings and ships; amugis for planks; apitong, a generic name for lumber from the panau tree and other dipterocarps used for lumber; baticulin or batikuling for sculpture and furniture; bansaluguin or bansalagin for wood bolts and handles of hammers and axes; calantas for cigar boxes, frames, and furnishings; camagong or ebano for furniture; dongol, dongon or dungon for house posts, ties, bridges, ships, and other construction; guijo or guiso for house construction; ipil for house posts, doors, and other construction; kakauati or madre de cacao for beams; lanete or laniti for furniture; lauan, a generic name for a number of species used for construction; magcono, magkano, or mangkono, a tree found in the Visayas and Mindanao used for pillars and house posts; mangachapoi, from a species of Hopea used for planks, bridges, and other construction; supa for furniture, boards, and other construction; tindalo or balayong (tugas among the Visayans) for furniture; and yacal or yakal, from different species of Hopea and Shorea used for rafters.

Some buildings were even aromatic. The Dutch stopped burning the Church of Capul in 1642 when they realized it was built of sandalwood, and took the boards with them instead. The qualities of such trees were passed on in friar chronicles, culminating in Fr Manuel Blanco’s Flora de Filipinas. Crates of samples were brought to the Philippine Exposition in 1887 in Madrid, in whose museums they can still be accessed today. Although these trees continue to be used for present-day construction and for the same purposes given, many more are unfortunately becoming rare.

Trozos or logs felled in the forests were ideally floated down river, tied to bamboo rafts. Hauling timber over land reached epic proportions. For instance, in order to transport the lumber for the convento of Santa Barbara in Pangasinan from Villasis, a distance of some 25 kilometers, 200 carabaos and 100 men were needed, and the parish priest was hoarse for 15 days. A rousing march from the town band spelled all the difference between extricating a log mired in mud and leaving it there forever.

Lumber could not be worked on immediately, because it had to be left to dry for two or more years to prevent warping. Wood was treated against insects with alquitran (tar), or it was buried in the sand pits of a river, or its sap was bled in saltwater. It was smoothened with the dried skin of the pagi or stingray. Surfaces were varnished with malapajo obtained from the resin of the balao tree; other finishes came from the sap of trees like the agacahac and apitong.

Houses and churches had roofs made of the long fronds of palms like the coconut, nipa, or lumbia, which was similar to the nipa except that it produced sago starch. The leaves of the lumbia could last up to eight years, twice than those of the nipa, and even longer if exposed to the smoke in the kitchen. In 17th century Visayas, as noted by Alzina in the 1660s, layers of bagakay bamboo slats were fastened on the rafters like roof shingles. Fused together and rendered offensive to termites by constant rain and smoke, these roofs could last up to 10 years without being changed. Much further north, in Paoay (Ilocos Norte), an expedition in 1710 noted how the church roof of thick caña boxo (buho) bamboo had been protected against fire by a layer of lime.

Calicanto Construction. The great Manila conflagration of 1583, however, showed the vulnerability of these wooden houses to fire. The first bishop of Manila Domingo de Salazar, who landed in 1581, encountered useful stone quarries along the banks of the Pasig in San Pedro Makati and Guadalupe. The Jesuit Antonio Sedeño, who arrived with Bp de Salazar, is credited for having introduced masonry to the Philippines: cutting stone, preparing the lime mixture, laying and aligning the stone blocks, and forming bricks and roof tiles. Contemporary scholars, however, remind us that this knowledge was not new to the Chinese, who already must have brought these skills with them to the islands.

Rocks destined for construction were pried loose (arrancada) from quarries (canteras or tibagan). From here they were dragged (arrastrada) or transported in carts (acarreada) to a clearing where they were hewn (labrada) into blocks. Blocks of stone were sold according to their sizes and use: sillares (about 1 x 1/2 x 1/2 yards, for facades and arches), sillaretes (for window frames), or tablillas (where we get the Visayan term tabriya or tabliya, describing the sheathing of pavements). These were floated along waterways, usually in Chinese-owned sampans, to landing places next to commercial centers such as the Puerta de Almacenes in Intramuros or the Estero de Binondo on the opposite bank of the Pasig. Buildings of cut stone were described as de silleria, de canteria, or de cal y canto, sometimes spelled calicanto. A mason was called a cantero or albañil.

Most of the buildings in Manila and Central Luzon were made of volcanic stuff, locally known as adobe. When freshly quarried, the material resembled the dried mud-and-straw bricks used in Mexico, which went by the same name. The whiter the stone, the more durable the construction. The hardiest variety was the bulik; less preferred were the gasang and the palanas, because they were prone to powdering. This weakness was countered by the application of a protective lime layer called palitada.

Limestone was a material that lent itself to fine cutting and carving. It was known by various names, depending on the region: apog, anapog, bato nga bukay, igang, or manunggul. So durable was this material that it did not need a layer of palitada. It could be obtained from inland quarries: the island of Guimaras was the source for limestone, which was brought to the adjacent province of Iloilo. It was also quarried from coral reefs during low tide. Dams were raised to hold back seawater, while the rocks were being cut loose. Coral was then shaped into blocks at the shore. In the Visayas the art of cutting coral was transformed into a virtual fine art, with blocks known as piedra de visayas fitting so precisely into each other that not even a razor blade could be inserted between them. Earlier churches, such as that of Baclayon in Bohol, used large blocks. But 19th century churches, like Anini-y in Antique and Lazi in Siquijor, used blocks of smaller size. The mid-19th century church of Loon, also in Bohol, with its subtle facade undulations was certainly one of the most sophisticated of its kind; unfortunately, it was totally destroyed in the earthquake of 2013.

Masonry was brought to Mindanao by Visayan settlers and the religious missionaries who worked among them. The church of Jimenez in Misamis Occidental is a fine example. Reef limestone churches were also built along the coastal areas of Luzon, notably Paoay in Ilocos Norte, Masinloc in Zambales, Balayan in Batangas, Gumaca in Quezon, and Indan in Camarines Norte. Piedra de visayas has enjoyed a resurgence in recent times as a veneer for concrete walls. It is now known commercially as Mactan stone, although this name negates its cultural provenance.

The abundance of a hard, black igneous rock in the southern Bicol towns surrounding Mayon Volcano characterized constructions in this area. The blocks of the church in Tabaco in Albay were uniquely chiseled with characters that appear to be either masons’s marks or symbols of stone suppliers. Comparable markings may be seen on the Malagonlong Bridge in Tayabas, Quezon Province. In a similar manner, signatures and drawings are inscribed on the bricks of the Church of Santo Domingo in Piat, Cagayan, and on the hardened mortar blocks of the church in Dapitan, Zamboanga del Norte.

Kuta Construction. In places where the art of hewing and cutting stone was unknown, builders raised walls from roughly chipped rocks, shales, or river stones. A pre-Hispanic rubblework wall was recently found enclosing an ancient settlement in Rakwaydi, Mahatao, in the Batanes. The lower portion of the traditional Ivatan house also consisted of the hurahed, a low wall cemented with chopped cogon, mud, lime or sand. The rubblework technique is still in use in the formation of rice terraces both in the Cordillera and the southern Tagalog highlands of Majayjay and Tayabas. The Cordillera rice terraces (payo among the Ifugao, payew among the Ibaloy) utilize rough-hewn stones kept together by clay. Both Ibaloy and Ifugao refer to stone walls of constructions like their rice terraces as toping or curiously, like their neighbors the Ilocanos, kabiti or kabite; its cognate, kinabiti, means “built of stone.”

This type of construction, known today as rubblework or riprap, was referred to in Spanish surveys as de mamposteria. An indigenous term that could replace the Spanish mamposteria for rubblework construction is kuta. Although kuta is presently understood as a fort, its hispanicized form, cota, appeared in Spanish chronicles and early dictionaries of Philippine languages in a more generic way: as a wall of rough stone bound together by mortar. One who built a cota was called a cotero. A kuta wall could be built of riprap stonework: piling and hammering chipped stones into place. It could also be raised by pouring layer after layer (lechada) of gravel mixed in mortar in a “wall” formed by sawali screens of split and woven bamboo.

This second type of construction was referred to as de piedra bituca, literally “of intestinal stone.” Since bituca meant intestines in many Philippine languages, piedra bituca referred to the mixture of stone and gravel poured into walls as filling. This gravel mixture was known in Spanish as cascajo. Pouring the lechada into the empty spaces was done through the aid of bancas, much like the constructions at Morong, Rizal. The discerning eye can spot the mat-like impressions of woven bamboo wallings on such places as the underside of a bridge in Badoc, Ilocos Norte; the convent vault in Tumauini, Isabela; the interior of a bulwark in Bulusan, Sorsogon; or the fort in Santa Fe, Cebu.

There are a number of extant early churches of kuta or rubblework construction. Many of them are in ruins and in out-of-the-way locations, which is why they are little known to the public. Among the oldest is the church in Malaueg in what is now Rizal, Cagayan, from the 1650s. Others are in Pindangan in San Fernando, La Union; Fotol, now known as Pudtol, Apayao; Pata, in what is now Namuac, Sanchez Mira, Cagayan; Maragondon in Cavite, and Santa Cruz in Marinduque. A great number of churches, cemeteries, small constructions and forts in the Visayas and Mindanao were described as de cota or de piedra bituca right up to the end of the 19th century. Although this might imply that certain towns could not afford good stone-cutting masons, many were in fact intended as “works in progress” and were eventually sheathed with cut stone slabs as funds became available.

Ladrillo Construction. The art of brickmaking was introduced at the same time as building in stone. Whereas brick is said to have been imported from Mexico during the first two decades of Spanish rule, Bp de Salazar could boast to the King of Spain, in a letter of 1595, that the Chinese supplied locally fired bricks that made imports unnecessary. These brick products included: ladrillos (bricks; lariyos in Pangasinan) used for walls, baldosas (floor tiles), and tejas (roof tiles; also the root word for tisa, chalk). The tejas were V-shaped in the Chinese manner, contrasting with the curved roof tiles of Spain and the Americas. They were of two types: canales which were laid down with the open side of the ‘V’ open towards the sky, and tapaderas which were placed inverted over the ridges formed by the canales. Rows of upturned tejas also doubled as drain spouts. Halves of roof tiles came in handy as calang (wedges) or space fillers in masonry walls, and were even used to line the bottom of salt-beds.

Different regions evolved their own brick recipes. For example, for the church of Janiuay in Iloilo, three types of soil were combined together: thick and clay-like balud from flood plains, fine and sandy hines from rice fields, and muddy anono-o from creeks. After being monotonously stomped by two carabaos, the mixture was formed into bricks by wooden moulds or alambre (wire) slicers, dried on mats, and fired-in kilns. Some of these kilns or hornos reached the size of watchtowers; the most impressive are those in Cagayan, especially the complex built by Fr Antonio Lobato, OP in Tuguegarao in the 1760s. Ladrillo architecture reached as far as Jolo, Sulu, exemplified by the church built there by the Jesuits in the late 19th century.

Bricks with raised decorations of flowers, fruit, and angel heads characterize many late 18th century churches built by the Dominicans in the Cagayan Valley. The most outstanding examples, such as the Tumauini Church in Isabela, were inscribed with numbers and initials to guide their assembly. In other areas such as in Iloilo and Negros, pilasters and rows of bricks were juxtaposed with coralstone for aesthetic effects.

Argamasa and Palitada. Stones and bricks were bound together by mortar, a mixture of lime, sand, and water, which was known as argamasa, hormigon, or mezcla. Pre-Hispanic Filipinos themselves were not strangers to lime (apog in many Philippine languages, but amed in Ivatan). They procured it from crushed oyster shells and chewed it as nganga among the Tagalogs or mama among the Visayans. Lime could be combined with coconut ashes to make a kind of soap, boiled with tuba wine to obtain honey, or mixed with tayumtayum leaves to produce a beautiful blue dye. During the Spanish era, lime for construction was obtained from limestone quarries or from coral rocks and seashells, which were ground and fired in an excavated pit or calero (chiman in the Batanes). The resulting quicklime was then slaked or kept moist in beds as a putty whose adhesive properties were best after three months.

The best sand (arena, balas, or buhangin ) was obtained from riverbeds, because it had to be as free from moisture-retaining salt as possible. If obtained from the seashore, sand and other materials had to be washed continuously for up to a year as in Atimonan, Quezon, or two rainy seasons. Two parts of sand were mixed with one part of lime if this was obtained from the seashore; three parts of sand were needed if the lime was quarried from the mountain.

To make the mixture more durable or binding, ingredients such as molasses, plant sap, and even eggs, were added. Such information, originally obtained from oral tradition, has also been sustained by historical and archival sources. To seal the dome of the Manila Cathedral in 1780, a lime mixture with miel de caña or molasses, duck eggs, and powdered brick, was used. Molasses was also used in the repair of the streets of Manila in the 1790s and in the church complex of Baclayon in Bohol in 1844. Mashed leaves of the puso-puso tree rendered the mortar water-resistant for the bathroom of the convento in Indang, Cavite in 1862. The same leaves were used in Majayjay, Laguna and in Sarrat, Ilocos Norte where it was called sablot. Sap from the law-at tree was used in the churches of the Parian district of Cebu and of Loay in Bohol, while hinaramay sap was used in Leon, Iloilo.

Fr Mariano Gomez ordered duck eggs for his church in Bacoor, Cavite in 1824; a little later, 200 duck eggs went into the mortar for the construction in Imus, Cavite. The “egg white recipe” in construction may explain the popularity of egg-yolk pastries such as pan de San Nicolas, yema, tocinodel cielo, and leche flan. Excess egg whites went to the baking of ladyfingers. The architectural value of eggs is ancient, as attested by its use in the 7th century CE monuments at Mamallapuram on the southeastern coast India.

Masonry walls had to be protected from erosion brought about by humidity and strong rains, and from decomposition from the roots of plants whose seeds were carried by wind or bird droppings. This protection was effected by a covering of stucco or plaster, a mixture of lime, yeso (gesso or gypsum), and cola (glue, often obtained from hides of animals such as the carabao). Sometimes the coating was augmented with malagquit, a glutinous rice. The plaster was applied with a trowel or paleta, which is why the process is appropriately called palitada; finer layers were brushed on with brochas. Masons erected palapala or bamboo scaffolding that was anchored into holes cut into the walls. Such holes may still be seen on the convento of Sarrat (Ilocos Norte), an indication that its coating of palitada was left incomplete as a consequence of the Philippine Revolution. The thickness of the palitada ranged from a light whitewash (blanqueo or blanqueadura) to several layers of lime plaster, the finest and final one on the surface. This covering was also useful in hiding imperfections on the wall, such as unsightly rough stones or gaps filled in by brick shards.

The stucco also provided a medium for decorative carving or painting on facade entrances, and interiors. The palitada by itself brightened up interiors, as it also improved the acoustics. White was not the only finish, as many other colors were used for the walls. Tints were obtained from organic materials, such as a popular yellow ochre or rust red from material known in Spanish as almagre but locally as barha, or a shade of blue from the añil or indigo plant. It is also listed down as maon, the color of denim. Other colors were imported in powder form and mixed with aceite de linaza (linseed oil). These were firmed up with carabao glue or even, in the case of San Pedro Tunasan in 1862, cow’s blood.

When paint was not available, the townspeople came up with ingenious devices to color up the surfaces of stone walls. In Malinao, round pebbles lined the cornices of the church. Giant clams or taclobo flanked openings in the church of Cagayancillo. Golden cowries, clams, snail shells, and corals were embedded like mosaics in the niche frames, pilasters, and cornices of the church in Guiuan.

Arquitectura Mestiza and Tabique Pampango. The twin dangers of fire and earthquake eventually led to the hybridization of local and hispanic architecture which was known as arquitectura mestiza in the 17th century. Although masonry walls presented a typical colonial construction, hidden from view was the native wooden framework with its timber posts that held up the roof and upper stories. An excellent example of this fusion is the church of Tubigon in Bohol. Although its facade and side walls are of cut stone, the apse at the back tells a different story. Here the kuta construction was left unfinished; the lack of stone slabs reveals the piedra bituca, which only partially encloses the stout timber pillars that rise above the incomplete wall.

A forgotten but nevertheless iconic development of arquitectura mestiza was the tabique pampango, a wall of light wooden materials covered with lime. The name for this local variant of wattle-and-daub construction was derived from the Spanish tabique, or a thin wall, and the still-unexplained descriptive pampango, perhaps because the earliest examples may have been noted in Pampanga. The wall was also called baras-baras, from the Cebuano word for mangrove, and referred to the use of mangrove wood, which was impervious to moisture.

The earliest known evidence of this construction method was a report on earthquake damage in the Ilocos. The churches of Bangar in La Union, and Candon, Bantay, and Cabugao in Ilocos Sur had walls of molave frames interwoven with bamboo and covered with lime, and set into low bases of stone. Although the document dates from 1709 or 1710, it was noted that most of these structures had been begun more than 10 years earlier. The first known author to mention tabique pampango was the Augustinian Joaquin Martinez de Zuñiga who, in 1799, described the provisional church of Santa Rosa, Laguna with walls of split bamboo woven into vertical pieces of timber.

The screen material held up by the vertical elements in a tabique depended on what was available in the area. The most common example was a kind of basket-weave of bamboo slats (Visayan salasa or sasa, or Tagalog patpat ), similar but stronger than amacan or sawali. In Zamboanga and Surigao, branches of the mangrove (baras-baras or talibugsuk) were used instead of bamboo. Another variation was the use of thin wooden planks instead of woven bamboo. These planks were first scored and serrated to ensure the adhesion of the mortar, and then laid horizontally, as in the convent at Loboc in Bohol and Urdaneta in Pangasinan. In Jabonga, Agusan del Norte and Balingasag, Misamis Oriental the planks were painstakingly swathed in cabo negro, a rope from the pith of idioc or kaong, more commonly known as palm tree.

Tabique, being light, economic, and versatile, was used in many structures, particularly those of a provisional nature or in zones distant from the larger towns. It was popular for exterior walls, especially on higher stories, as on the second floor of the bahay na bato or the cimborio or dome of a church. In an 1883 survey, 17 of 33 churches in Bohol had walls of tabique pampango. However, with the passage of time, tabique tended to flake and finally break apart, especially if the framework was improperly aged or treated. The Earthquake Ordinances of 1880 expressly forbade the use of tabique pampango in further construction, and decreed that metal sheets or wooden planks would be utilized.

Other Building Materials. In place of glass, palm-sized window panes were made from the shell of the capiz or tipay, the window oyster. These translucent clams allowed light to filter through yet were sturdy enough to withstand storms. They were mounted onto a wooden lattice of different colors: white from the molave, red from the barayong or naga, or black from ebony.

Pavements, sidewalks, stairways and streets were paved with heavy slabs of granite brought by junks from southern China, hence they were popularly called piedra china.

During the mid-19th century, improved shipping and the opening of the Suez Canal allowed the importation of modern and prestigious building materials, such as clear or colored glass panes, azulejos or glazed tiles, black marble, stamped-metal sheets for ceilings, and cast-iron fixtures and hardware. Because tile roofs broke during earthquakes and posed a hazard to the passersby, clay tejas were replaced by metal sheets (planchas) made of sim (zinc) or hierro galvanizado (galvanized iron). These were imported from places like Australia, bearing such brands as Emu or Three Crowns. After the devastating earthquake of 18 Jul 1880, the Consultative Council for Public Works also issued ordinances that stipulated, among other things, the preference for hydraulic or Portland cement over other materials.

Although influenced by Chinese blue and white, through the Arabs who imitated Chinese porcelain, not all azulejos were blue; a good number were polychromed. These tiles were used as finishing for walls and floors, as in the Nagcarlan Church in Laguna; the Basey Church in Samar, where the tiles used are predominantly yellow; and in the Archdiocesan Seminary of Naga, Camarines Sur, where the tiles are polychromed. Black marble, alternated with white to produce a checkerboard or harlequin pattern, was used to replace the wooden floors of many churches and other public buildings. The Machuca Company in Manila produced a cement version of these tiles, which used marble dust and were very popular during the 20th century.

Master Builders, Engineers, Architects. In the absence of professional architects, public construction was initiated by both civil and religious authority from the 16th to the 18th centuries, and relied on the ingenuity and training of the priest or the local official. Although the Spanish crown sent military engineers to supervise construction throughout the colonial period, it was in 1805 that the corps of government engineers was organized and only in 1867 that the Obras Publicas was established. By the late 19th century, there was a sufficient number of professionally trained builders and architects to take charge of construction.

Early builders may have relied on classic manuals, such as the 1st century BC’s Ten Books on Architecture by the Roman architect Vitruvius. Sebastiano Serlio’s Seven Books of Architecture published in 1537, found its way to the University of Santo Tomas’s rare book collection, suggesting that the work was known, if not consulted by friar builders. The practical knowledge gained by friars and priests may have been codified. The Augustinian Juan de Albarran, builder of the Santo Niño Shrine in Cebu in 1735, wrote down his experience of building as a guide for future friar-builders.

Misrepresented in 19th- and 20th-century bibliographies as a full-blown architectural handbook is Modo de Construir Iglesias y Conventos en las Islas Filipinas (Ways of Constructing Churches and Conventos in the Philippine Islands), the manuscript written in 1739 which is part of a general report on the Santo Niño Shrine. The first four pages of the manuscript report the friar’s practical experience in procuring piedra de visayas and lime for construction. The remaining folios contain a general discussion on architecture based on European handbooks especially those written by Palladio, Juan de Arfe, and Juan de Nicolas. Another 19th century architectural handbook by Manuel Herbella y Perez, Manual de Construcciones y de Fortificacion de Campaña en Filipinas (Manual of Buildings and of Campaign Fortification in the Philippines), published 1882, was primarily a guide for military construction.

The actual business of building, both for public and private projects, was handled by the maestros de obras (master builders) who imbibed their skills from friars, military engineers, and other learned persons, and from practical experience. Pedro Jusepe, master builder of the walls of Intramuros in 1591, was probably a Filipino. Filipinos were most probably already at the helm of construction projects within two decades after the founding of Manila. Another master carpenter-contractor was Jeronimo Tongco, who also worked on the walls of Intramuros. Bartolome Palatino was another master builder from the 19th century who built the facade of the Morong Church from 1850 to 1853. Severo Sacramento was commissioned to renovate the Tayabas Church from 1855 to 1860. The government sought to professionalize the work of the maestros by opening schools of arts and trades in Pampanga, Iloilo, and Manila. In 1890, the Manila school graduated Arcadio Arellano, its most outstanding maestro.

Construction workers were paid a daily wage, but an equally common practice was to contract the work or the procurement of material to the maestro or to some person. The contractual system, calledpakyaw, which survives to the present, seems to have been favored by the Chinese. The government also employed a system ofpolo y servicio, which meant that able-bodied males were compelled to render labor for public construction for a period of 60 days per year. Exceptions were allowed for the sickly, theprincipalia(elite), and those in military service. This system of conscripted labor was used for infrastructure, like the building of roads, bridges, forts, and harbors. During the 17th century, most conscripted labor in Luzon went toward the construction of galleons—from felling timber, to hewing, to hauling it to the ports where the ships were made. Parish priests sometimes requested authorization from the government to use conscripted labor for the construction and repair of ecclesiastical buildings; such authorization, however, was at times grudgingly given. Not all labor was human, it must be noted. The construction of the Jesuit church in the early 1620s was aided by an elephant from Cambodia, a gift from the governor-general.

The American Colonial Tradition

The United States gained control of the Philippines in 1898, and in 1901, the Philippine Commission, the ruling body of the Philippines, created the Bureau of Architecture and Control of Public Buildings. Edgar Bourne was appointed as the first consulting architect of the Bureau. He designed the Government Laboratory, between Padre Faura and Pedro Gil, in the Mission Revival style. Although the Bureau was subsequently abolished on 1 Nov 1905 and relegated to the level of a division, these acts of the colonial government placed the supervision and control of the construction and repair of public buildings squarely in government hands. In 1904, the American Commissioner William Cameron Forbes asked Daniel Burnham to come to the Philippines to make recommendations for the amelioration of Manila and Baguio. Burnham asked for William E. Parsons to serve as consulting architect for the Philippines, a post Parsons occupied from 1905 to 1914. In 1914, he was joined by George Fenhagen, and in 1916, by Ralph Harrington Doane who served until 1918.

Under the Jones Law, a Division of Architecture was created in which American and Filipino architects were employed. Carlos A. Barreto, Antonio Toledo, Tomas Mapua, and Juan Arellano worked with Parsons, Fenhagen, and Doane. Parsons favored the use of reinforced concrete against natural stone.

Concrete is produced by mixing cement, sand, gravel or aggregate—pebbles or crushed stones—and water, and pouring this mixture into forms where it dries and hardens, becoming stone-like. The strength of concrete depends on the ratio of cement to sand and stone and the amount of water used. The ancient Romans used concrete made of broken bricks or stones and a cement of lime and volcanic ash. It was not exposed but faced with brick or finely cut stone.

Unlike the Romans, modern cement is produced by burning and pulverizing a mixture of clay and limestone. Reinforced concrete or ferroconcrete, is concrete with steel bars laid in accordance with calculations for stress. While concrete has a very heavy resistance to compression, its tensile strength is only one-tenth of its compressive strength. Thus, in a slab or beam supported at both ends, where a load produces compression in the upper section and tension in the lower, steel bars are laid in the lower section to take the tension. In a cantilevered slab or beam, which is supported at one end, the reverse occurs. The upper section is subjected to tensile stress, and the lower to compressive. Thus the position of the steel bars is reversed.

Reinforced concrete is remarkable for both its durability and its plasticity. It can be shaped into thin shells, which are strengthened by their curvature, such as domes, barrel roofs, saddle roofs, and hypar or hyperbolic paraboloid roofs and umbrella-like shapes. It is also used in folded plate construction. Long thin slabs are joined at their long edges to form what look like pleats or accordion folds, thereby reinforcing each other to produce rigidity.

While concrete was invented by the Romans, reinforced concrete was invented by the French. After the decline of the Roman Empire, concrete fell into disuse. It was revived in France in the 18th century. The use of metal reinforcements came later. In the 1830s concrete floors were constructed with an iron network. In the late 1870s concrete columns and beams were reinforced with iron bars. Calculations for the design of concrete structures developed in the 1870s in Germany and the US. Towards the end of the century factories with concrete framework were constructed. The development of steel as a building material led to further advances, such as prestressing.

Reinforced concrete was introduced in the Philippines during the early American colonial period. The first beneficiaries of this type of construction were the public elementary buildings, for which the amount of one million pesos was allocated by the Gabaldon Act of 1907. Reinforced concrete also lends itself to prefabrication. Building components, such as wall sections, floor slabs, columns, and beams, can be produced in a factory, then transported and assembled at the building site.

The use of hollow cement blocks was also introduced during the American era. Machine or hand-operated molds were popular. Initially, cement was imported from Japan and China until the first cement plant was opened in Binangonan, Rizal. This town was a traditional source of limestone since the Spanish era. As more quarries of limestone and cement factories were built, the dependence on imported cement diminished.

Following Burnham’s dictum that the Spanish colonial architecture should be the basis of a new style of architecture for the Philippines, Parsons made use or arches, plain walls, and capiz windows in such buildings as the Philippine General Hospital and the Army-Navy Club. Cement, the construction material favored by the American colonial government, was used not only for walls and structural members but also for precast ornaments and fixtures, like classical capitals, friezes, and reliefs for pediments. Government builders favored the neoclassical style, while in the 1930s art deco, which favored ornamentation and precast-cement moldings and relief, became popular.

Glass blocks, stained glass, and Bakelite were materials frequently used in art deco and art nouveau designs. Glass blocks allowed light to enter and were used on both exterior and interior walls. Stained glass, used previously in churches, found its way into domestic architecture. Bakelite, a precursor of plastic, was used for doorknobs, pulls, and appliances. Wrought iron, already popular since the Spanish colonial era, found new expressions in art deco geometric and stylized floral motifs. Construction steel was imported from the US, and used to build the bridges built to span rivers and chasms

The Gabaldon schoolhouse was perhaps the most disseminated building type because it was built in every city and municipality, and even in the city districts and the municipality’s barrios. The design was used for many schools for both the primary and tertiary levels. As designed by Parsons, the schoolhouse adapted many features of vernacular architecture. It was raised from the ground to protect it from dampness and cold. It was anchored by concrete foundations on which wood or reinforced concrete posts supported a lintel and post construction. Its roof was pitched like the bahay kubo and the bahay na bato. It used hardwood for floors and partitions and had a transom for light and ventilation. Its windows were awning type like the bahay kubo and used capiz panes for the window shutters.

Post-World War II Traditions

The postwar period ushered in massive rebuilding. While reinforced concrete, steel framing for bridges, and other materials of the American era continued to be used, new materials and building techniques were introduced. Steel frame construction and reinforced concrete allowed the construction of higher buildings. Other technological advances, such as prefabrication and prestressed concrete, allowed the rapid construction of buildings and the multiplication of housing units to meet the need of a growing population.

Prefabrication refers to the manufacture of buildings or their components before they are assembled or installed at the construction site. Prefabrication of building parts originated in England in the late 18th century, when cast iron began to be used in the construction of bridges and factories. It was further developed in the United States in the 19th century when metal items, such as structural members, window frames, and facade panels, were mass-produced. In the 20th century, aluminum curtain walls were manufactured for high-rise buildings. With the development of precast concrete, wall panels and floor slabs began to be prefabricated. The invention of prestressing has led to the prefabrication of concrete girders and beams for bridges, elevated highways, and buildings.

Prefabrication was more intensively developed in the mid-20th century with the increasing shortage of skilled labor, the rise in the volume of construction, and the more extensive use of modular design based on standard measurements. Prefabrication has been especially suitable for low-cost housing and school buildings.

The oldest and most famous example of prefabricated construction in the Philippines is the all-steel San Sebastian Basilica, all parts of which were manufactured in Belgium, shipped to Manila, and assembled at the site. Mass housing in Vitas, Tondo, Manila consists of prefabricated units, which are shaped like boxes and stacked to a height of four stories in staggered arrangement, so that additional units are created in the intervening space.

Prestressed concrete marks a further development in concrete construction. Prestressing means subjecting a reinforced-concrete beam to stress before it takes on the load for which it was designed. Prestressing has made it possible to reduce the depth of concrete beams and to increase their span.

A reinforced-concrete beam can be designed to span any length. However, the longer the span, the deeper the beam should be. Prestressing reduces the size of a concrete beam by increasing its strength through induced stresses that result in greater resistance to the load.

In pre-tensioning, the tendons or cables that reinforce the beam are pulled and held in tension before the concrete is poured and until it has hardened. The tendons are then released and their tension compresses the concrete, increasing its strength. In post-tensioning, the tendons are enclosed in a sleeve or tube set in the concrete so that they do not directly touch it. When the concrete has hardened, the tendons are pulled against it, thereby compressing it.

In post-tensioning, the stress on the tendons can be adjusted to suit the load. The principle of prestressing can be illustrated by tightly pressing together a row of books at both ends and lifting them up. The books are held together by compression and can support the weight of an object placed on them.

The use of prestressed concrete beams has enabled architects to design large clear spaces, such as lobbies, halls, and supermarkets with the fewest possible supports, or without any intervening supports.

Contemporary Materials. The building boom that began in urban centers during the late 1980s has introduced new construction materials. Many large hardware firms usually specialize in one product alone, i.e. tiles. The materials mostly come from China but there are also materials from Europe, other parts of Southeast Asia and the Philippines. Some are building materials like ficem, fiber and cement boards, gypsum boards for dry walling, dense styrofoam for insulation, powder-coated long-span roofing, shingles, and prefabricated aluminum windows. Glass glazing has increased in dimensions and is favored by high-rise buildings. Improvement in tempering glass has made it a durable external material. For finishes, polished granite from China in various colors, glass blocks, and ceramic tiles of various colors and textures, even imitating the texture of stone, wood, and metal, are used. Composite materials have also been introduced for internal wall and flooring.

For outdoors, architects are now favoring prefabricated cladding in cement, painted aluminum and hard vinyl. As for appliances like sinks and bathrooms, prefabricated shower rooms, bathroom fixtures and plastic doors have been introduced.

Bamboo has also enjoyed a resurgence. It is a fine natural material that meets all the criteria as a sustainable building construction material. With the drastic loss of Philippine forests in the past 40 years, there is need to source alternative materials, besides precious hardwoods, to build homes. With population growth, there is also a call for alternative shelters. Bamboo has emerged as an ideal candidate because it is quick-growing and versatile.

Bamboo has a tensile strength equal to that of steel, and a compressive strength comparable to concrete: 10,000 lbs per square inch. When harvested at the right stage of its growth, it can be used creatively to maximize its potential, even structurally. When the poles are harvested when they are between three and six years old, cleaned of thorns and protective sheets and treated with a diluted borax solution, they can last for a long time. Stored above the ground, away from ultraviolet rays of the sun, bamboo will keep. he decorative features of bamboo have also been appreciated when used as veneers for walls, floors, furniture and other decorative items.  Written by Ma. text:
Design in architecture refers to the planning, whether by professional architects or folk builders, of any structure before it is built or as it is being built. It is the creative process that aims to produce a structure, private or public, that fulfills the needs of its future occupants or users. It considers the environment, culture, and traditions of these occupants; the climate, location, and other environmental factors; construction methods and equipment, available materials, funds, workers, basic services, and other circumstances or conditions—religious, social, political, economic—that have or will have an effect on the structure that is being planned.

As an art, architecture has elements of both painting and sculpture. In designing the facade and other elevations of a building, the architect approaches his task like a painter, working in two dimensions, as he composes an arrangement of lines and planes and considers light, shadow, and color. Taking the three-dimensional approach of a sculptor, the architect envisions the building as a volume or an assemblage of volumes—cubes, oblong blocks, pyramids, cylinders, or hemispheres.

What makes architecture distinct from painting and sculpture is the design and ordering of space for the purpose of satisfying human needs, whether it is the bodily need for shelter or the psychological need for an aesthetic or spiritual experience. A building is primarily a space defined and organized by structure. As a work of art, a building is designed not only to possess beauty but also to express meaning.

 

As a science, architecture is concerned with the usefulness and durability of a building. The planning of interior spaces, including their forms, dimensions, interrelations, and their relation with the environment, has to do with the function or purpose of a building. Since a building is primarily a shelter meant to provide protection from the elements, its design takes into account the climate features of the location: the heat of the sun, the volume of rain, and the direction of the wind. In a tropical setting, a building is expected to keep out heat and rain, and let in air for ventilation.

Designing a building for durability requires knowledge of materials and structural systems. The design of space is inseparable from the design of the structure, which in simpler forms would consist of foundations; vertical supports, such as columns and piers; and horizontal supports, such as beams and girders, walls, floors, and the roof. More sophisticated structures could employ arches, vaults, domes, buttresses, space frames, or cantilevers.

Architecture is not only the work of an individual designer but also the product of a culture, and as such it reflects the values and the spirit of its time. The major architectural works of a historical period signify its dominant mood: whether this be the longing for an experience of the divine, the glorification of secular power, the affirmation of human dignity, the desire for efficiency, or the exaltation of commerce and technology. Since works of architecture are commissioned by patrons or clients, they also represent the interests of the dominant class, whether these be political, economic, or cultural. Of all the arts, architecture is the most visible and the most ubiquitous, since it comprises the human-made part of the environment, and serves the universal need for shelter. It is the art that is most closely bound with one’s daily life, for to live is to be in shelter.

 

Design Process. The process of architectural design begins with defining the purpose and requirements of a building as envisioned by the owner or client. The architect then studies the proposed site of the building, its size, shape, orientation, location, topography, and the immediate as well as larger environment. Research prior to actual design would include study of the intended use of the building, the various activities, and the movement of people and things within and outside. In the case of houses, the lifestyle of the residents would be the object of study. Aside from organizing space for maximum efficiency, the designer also considers cultural requirements, as well as the expressive or symbolic function of the building.

The preliminary phase of design includes diagrams and sketches in which concepts are translated into basic forms or schemes. The first products of design are the floor plan and the site plan—the design of the interior space and its relation to the site and the environment—seen in terms of the two dimensions of length and width.

With the floor plan as basis, the architect proceeds to designing the space with its third dimension of height. The drawings of all sides of the exterior of a building are called elevations. To show the interior space of the building, the architect draws longitudinal and cross sections, imagining a line or invisible plain cutting through the building at certain points. More realistic views of the building are presented in the perspectives, both exterior and interior, which may be rendered in color. Plans and elevations form the preliminary drawings which are presented to the client for approval.

The artistic conception of the building is followed or accompanied by the structural design, or the engineering aspect of architecture. Taking into account the load that the spaces will carry, the length, width, and height of the spaces, the bearing strength of the soil, wind pressure, the force of earthquakes, and the strength of construction materials, the structural engineer designs the foundations, columns, beams, walls, and floors of the building. The design of electrical, plumbing, air-conditioning, mechanical, and fire-control systems is assigned to specialists. Others specialists such as interior designers and landscape architects, may be engaged by the architect.

After the client approves the preliminary drawings, the architect prepares the working drawings in specifications. The working drawings show all the details of construction, and the specifications lay down instructions to supplement the plans and specify the quality or brands of materials or items to be used or installed. The drawings and specifications are given to building contractors who prepare estimates and submit bids. Upon the award of the contract, construction begins. The drawings and specifications are essential elements of the contract made between the owner and the builder or contractor.

With the advent of the computer, the term “design” has not been limited to architecture but now includes a variety of activities and products and many disciplines. Advanced computer-aided design (CAD) software has made it convenient for architects and designers to make a preliminary design and modify it, represent it in varying light and weather conditions, change the color, texture, and details of an architectural plan. CAD can represent material like wood, natural stone, cement, or ceramic in a way that gives the owner and the builder an idea what the finished work will be. With CAD, it is also possible to integrate interior design so that furnishings such as light fixtures, furniture, carpets, and curtains can be seen in a computer rendered design. CAD can also make perspective and 3D drawings so that a building can be visually experienced. More and more architects are creating walkthroughs and flyovers so that a client or a future user can have an idea what the building will be like. Digital technology has allowed for a virtual experience of a structure long before it is built. Architectural design is evolving toward not just seeing a plan before it is executed, but having a computer-aided experience of the plan. Design is increasingly about virtual experience, so that architectural design and related fields, like landscape, interior, furniture, and product design are coalescing to become experience-design. With the invention of 3D printing it is possible to have models that are partially or fully computerized, so that a level of precision not possible with handcrafted models can be achieved.

Once the design and the list of materials are agreed upon, contractors and subcontractors and the team of experts are chosen and the budget fixed. Contractors then assemble their teams of workers, take care of getting the building permits, and set up the working conditions on the site. The architect, as representative of the owner or client, supervises or inspects the construction, seeing to it that plans and specifications are faithfully followed.

Evolution of Design. In the Philippines, the design of indigenous houses resulted from a long evolution that began with rudimentary shelter, such as the lean-to or windscreen made from twigs and leaves. The house-form developed as the occupants devised better ways of protecting themselves from the elements—from rain, strong winds, the heat of the sun, the dampness of the ground, and from insects, animals, and enemies. Interaction with the environment led to the discovery of better forms of shelter, more durable building materials, and better methods of construction. As the primitive economy improved, so did the way of life develop through increasing needs and expectations and the growing capacity to satisfy them. Shelters became larger if there was need for more space, became more sturdily constructed, and better adapted to the climate and environment.

Indigenous house forms in their development became standardized, almost rigidly so, for a particular community. Thus, houses are identical, and serve as the identification of a community. The Ifugao house, for example, while following a basic form, has distinctive local variants in Lagaue, Banaue, and Mayoyao, and each variant is the norm for that community. Several communities in a region could employ the same particular feature but subject to local variations. For example, Ifugao, Bontok, Kankanaey, and Sagada houses use the four-post, two-girder, three-joist frame, yet each community has a distinctive house form.

The bahay kubo (nipa hut) is built on a basic principle (i.e., a living space raised on stilts and covered by a hip or gable roof). Its form, like that of the indigenous house, has been dictated by needs and functions. But, unlike the indigenous house, the bahay kubo avails of some freedom of design. Floor plans, dimensions, materials, and features may vary. Sidings could be of split bamboo, flattened bamboo, woven bamboo strips, or thatch. Shutters may swing out or slide to the sides. There may be a covered porch or an open platform, or the roof may extend over an area on ground level. The design of the house is determined by the preferences of the owner. The bahay kubo is vernacular architecture characterized by some measure of individuality.

Architectural design during the Spanish colonial period may be classified into two types: the design produced by architects, engineers, or friars, closely following European models; and the design that resulted from the interaction of indigenous forms and Western architectural styles. The first includes churches, government buildings, and fortifications that were built in accordance with professionally prepared plans and under close supervision by the Spanish friars, architects, and engineers. The churches and civic buildings in Intramuros and the forts built in various parts of the country are the best examples of this type. The second type includes houses in Intramuros built during the Spanish colonial period, which combined local wooden construction with stone walls in the European style, the bahay kubo built in other sections of Manila and in the provincial towns, and the churches built in the missions and parishes outside Manila. The design of houses were probably the work of maestros de obras (master builders) and head masons, who were not only skilled workers but also artists to some extent. Their talents were employed not only in the design of architectural ornaments, such as wooden tracery and stone carvings, but also in the design of spaces and functional features, such as the caida (receiving hall), the sala (living room), the volada (gallery), and the escalera (staircase). Houses were designed with due regard for the preferences of the owner, who very likely decided how large the house and its rooms should be, what materials should be used, and how the structure should be decorated.

Architectural design during the Spanish colonial period reflects the major concerns of Spain in the Philippines, namely, the establishment and propagation of the Catholic religion; the strengthening of colonial rule; the defense of the regime from enemies, whether from within or from without; the extension of social services to the population; and the development of the economy. The most impressive landmarks left by the Spanish rule are the churches and fortresses and the few remaining government buildings. However, the Spaniards also built schools, hospitals, factories, commercial buildings, and a railway system.

Provincial churches and the bahay na bato (stone house) stand as memorials to the encounter and synthesis of native and Spanish culture. They signify the native response to the introduction of Western culture, a response characterized by hospitable acceptance. Philippine architectural design in this period developed through the interactions between native and immigrant designs.

The profession of architecture gained prominence in the 19th century as architects, mostly Spaniards, were engaged for the design of a wide variety of structures, including the sumptuous homes of the affluent. It must be noted, however, that architectural plans from the 19th century include designs for middle-class residences.

Since there were no architectural schools in the country during the Spanish regime, Filipinos like Felix Roxas Sr had to go abroad to study architecture. A gifted Filipino who was inclined to architecture but could not afford to study abroad could become at most a maestro de obras, like Arcadio Arellano. Although lacking formal architectural training, Arellano succeeded in designing buildings in the Gothic revival, neo-Renaissance, neobaroque, and art nouveau styles.

The American colonial period witnessed the emergence of the Filipino architect, who in the early decades was invariably trained abroad. The first major buildings of that era were, however, the work of an American architect, William E. Parsons, who had been chosen by Daniel H. Burnham to implement his development plans for Manila and Baguio. The buildings of the early years of America in the Philippines reflected the thrusts of her colonial policy: public education, public health, training in self-government, and economic development. The Philippine General Hospital, the Philippine Normal School, the University of the Philippines (UP), and the Manila Hotel were all products of this policy. Roads and bridges were built to link the various parts of the country, while schools and provincial capitols were constructed at an impressive pace beyond the pueblo complex.

In his early buildings, Parsons aimed to create a new architectural style that evoked the Spanish colonial buildings in Manila yet at the same time employed modern methods of construction. Reinforced concrete was used extensively and its smooth, plain surfaces characterized the new style. The modernism of Parsons did not last very long, for he shifted to neoclassicism before he ended his employment in the Philippines. However, he bequeathed this style to the American and Filipino architects who succeeded him at the Bureau of Public Works.

Architectural design in the Philippines in the 20th century consisted of the reproduction of historical or revivalist styles, the adaptation of modern styles, such as art deco and the International style, and the effort to create a distinct Filipino style.

As in the Spanish colonial period, the development of architectural design was influenced by foreign styles. However, there has been a growing appreciation of indigenous architecture as a source for a contemporary Filipino style. This is exemplified by the Tahanang Pilipino, designed by Francisco Mañosa, which is a building notable for its evocation of folk architecture.

Although design by imitation is evident in some buildings, there is just as visible an attempt to be original and truly creative. A building like Leandro Locsin’s Church of the Holy Sacrifice at the UP represents a breakthrough in design. Departing from conventional forms, the airy circular church shows the way to the development of architecture that is modern and tropical. At the same time it serves as a symbol of what the church should be—accessible to all and always welcoming. The building is open all around; there are no doors.

The concept of architecture as sculpture has produced buildings of great visual impact. One such building is the Cultural Center of the Philippines Main Building, designed by Locsin, which impresses the viewer as a giant piece of geometric sculpture.

An important element of contemporary architectural design is technology, which includes structural design and the various convenience systems, like air-conditioning, fire control, security, elevators and escalators, and electrical and plumbing systems. A building is no longer simply space and structure, but a complex of machines and systems that have to be integrated into an object of aesthetic delight.

From the indigenous tradition through the Spanish colonial period and the American colonial period to the present, Philippine architectural design has developed from the simple response to the environment and social needs, through the encounter and reconciliation with a foreign culture, to the task of synthesizing the country’s cultural heritage, the architect’s originality, and the blessings of modern technology.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III, with notes from René B. Javellana
