text:
Heritage conservation is the maintenance and preventive care for buildings, other architectural structures, and open sites to prolong their existence and their usefulness. Architecturally, heritage refers to built structures and open spaces or sites of antiquity that are significant to a culture because of historical, social, cultural, artistic, or economic reasons, which warrant their conservation. The time measure for antiquity varies from place to place. Legislation on this matter is not uniform. Common time measures are 50, 75, or 100 years.

These structures and sites are called heritage or patrimony because they are considered as being valuable and worthy of being passed on to succeeding generations as gifts from the past (heritage) or inheritance from their ancestors (patrimony). Architecture is classified as tangible heritage, because there is a physical object or a place that remains over time. Tangible heritage is contrasted to intangible heritage which leaves no physical remains but disappears after a period of time. The term is usually applied to performances of music, dance, and theater or transitory things like events and festivities or even to cuisine, which is consumed.

Countries or nongovernmental organizations (NGOs) focusing on heritage conservation have certain systems for identifying and recognizing heritage structures and sites, marking them, and protecting them for the future. Heritage conservation laws have been passed in many countries and an international effort at conservation is overseen by UNESCO, established in 1945, especially through the Convention Concerning the Protection of World Cultural and Natural Heritage, adopted by the UNESCO General Conference on 16 Nov 1972. This convention gave rise to the inscription of structures, sites, and cultural routes on the World Heritage List

 

The field of heritage conservation uses a number of specific terms that are often confused. Consolidation refers to major maintenance work that addresses threats to a structure or site. For instance, a wall that may have cracked after an earthquake has to be made whole again or consolidated, by repairing, or even strengthening the structure. Restoration means returning a structure or site to its earliest or most historic stage. Later additions or accretions, as well as ornaments and layers of paint, may be removed. A decision may have to be made about a historical structure or site as to which era it will be restored to. Reconstruction means rebuilding a structure following the original plans and building techniques after massive destruction following damages caused by nature, such as floods and earthquake; by accidents, or by humans, as happens during a war. Renovation is changing a part or the entirety of a heritage structure or site. Some renovations may be done if the heritage being renovated is not unique or irreplaceable. For instance, if a row of townhouses is deemed historical, the best of the units may be conserved and the rest remodeled. Finally, architectural reuse means restoring a heritage structure or site but using it for another purpose that will not destroy the structure or radically alter its historical value. For instance, a school or municipio may be converted into a museum.

Heritage Conservation as Global Movement. The history of heritage conservation shows that conservation is a contested concept and there is no unanimity about this matter. Prior to the 20th century, conservation was not an issue. Renaissance popes, for example, renovated Rome by tearing down the 4th century Basilica of St Peter and replacing it with a Renaissance-baroque structure. When Giancarlo Bernini was commissioned to do the colonnade at the Piazza San Pietro at the Vatican, he had buildings demolished. Napoleon Bonaparte renovated the street plans of Paris by making wide boulevards and avenues that involved demolition of older structures. Napoleon’s urban renewal of Paris meant a loss of old buildings and a radical change of the city’s layout. Even up to the 20th century, Benito Mussolini built Via della Conciliazione to mark the accord between the Vatican and the Italian state in 1936. In 1950, an Egyptian obelisk was placed at the center of the piazza.

After World War II, a new consciousness about the past and its heritage emerged. The intellectual root of this movement goes back to the previous century, when a historical sense began pervading Western thought. With the development of critical history, advances in archaeology, paleography, conservation of artifacts, the birth of the social disciplines of ethnography and anthropology, and the theoretical reflections and theories on change and evolution by thinkers like Fredrick Hegel, Charles Darwin, and Russell Wallace, European thought was invaded by a sense of flux.

Hegel presented an optimistic picture of progress, from thesis facing antithesis and evolving into a higher synthesis, while Darwin painted an evolutionary picture of the survival of the fittest, the world wars shook the foundations of this idealistic optimism. The Athens Charter of 1931 had already articulated the urgency of preserving and restoring ancient buildings and, after World War II, the 1931 Charter became the starting point for the heritage conservation movement. This was articulated further in national declarations and in the work of international agencies like the International Council of Museums and UNESCO.

World War II saw the destruction not just of sites, structures, and artifacts, but the very possibility that an entire group of people could be obliterated. While the Nazi-sponsored Holocaust sent six million Jews to their death, thousands of noncombatants were killed in the battles that ensued around the world, and ended with the catastrophic dawning of the atomic age as the first atom bombs were dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

After the war, the response to the possibility that the past could and would be obliterated inspired a spirited response to restore, rebuild, and conserve. The European movement of heritage conservation began by focusing on specific sites and buildings. This was part of the postwar effort at reconstruction. The concern that the past would be completely cut off from the present inspired the rebuilding of historic architecture rather than replacing them with more modern and functional ones.

In the 1950s, the heritage conservation movement became widespread in Europe as countries began to rebuild after the devastation of World War II. Although there were previous initiatives to preserve the past, the consciousness that the past was vital to society and to humanity was heightened during the postwar era.

That Europe should gravitate toward architectural reconstruction is probably rooted in the European sense of space. The very word “civilization” is etymologically derived from the Latincives,civitas, meaning city. “City” in the classical Roman sense consisted of built structures laid out in space according to plan. The Romanciveswas a well-ordered space for a society organized according to Roman law. The first century Roman architect Vitruvius described buildings as having three qualities: utility, monumentality, and permanence. Permanence was structurally expressed in the use of enduring material like stone and brick or cement; monumentality in buildings that made a statement; utility in buildings that served a purpose. The classical tradition, modified by different cultural influences—Byzantine, Moorish, and the like—was reinterpreted and reinforced by the classicism of the Renaissance and revivalist architecture that laid the foundation for the European urbanscape.

The first impulse of conservation focuses on buildings that marked, delineated, and defined European space, because these buildings were icons of European civilization. Heritage was equated, especially in the popular mind, with buildings and sites. Not surprising too is the fact that the early listings in the UNESCO World Heritage List are single detached buildings. We note for instance, how many single buildings are listed in Spain, including the popular shrine of Santiago de Compostela.

But as the heritage conservation movement became global, the movement was challenged by differing but culturally defined sense of heritage. The Venice charter of 1964 defined “an historic monument” as embracing “not only the single architectural work but also the urban and rural setting or an historical event. This applies not only to the great works of art but also to more modest works of the past, which have acquired cultural significance with the passing of time.”

As the movement spread to Southeast Asia, heritage conservation came face to face with a completely different philosophy of space. Despite the age of many Asian civilizations, many Southeast Asian countries can show little by way of precolonial historic architecture and the corresponding urbanscape. The exceptions would be Cambodia, Thailand, and Laos with their Hindu and Buddhist temples and complexes; Java with Prambanan and Borobudur; and the Kingdoms of Ayutthaya and Sukothai in Thailand. Almost always, surviving historic architecture and urbanscapes are related to religion and royalty. But even the remains of royal palaces are incomplete. Many of the historic remains in Ayutthaya and Ratu Boko in the hills of Gunung Kidul are mere foundations. The wooden superstructure has all but disappeared.

What has been classified as vernacular architecture in the West, and traditionally regarded as secondary after the monumental type of architecture, comprises most of Southeast Asian architectural heritage. Stone monuments, such as Prambanan or the chedis of Thailand, are not so much shelters as they are markers—singular points in the landscape that mark sacred spaces for religious rites. It is postulated that around these sites were villages and dwelling complexes for monks and other religious functionaries, but the evidence is scant or not immediately visible, as in Borobudur.

Much of rural Southeast Asia remains agricultural. And agrarian cultures are closely bound to the cyclic rhythms of nature. Asian vernacular architecture tends to imitate this cycle: for instance, dwellings, mostly timber and thatch, renewed after being damaged by typhoons or earthquake or fire. Bali’s Pura Besakih, built on the slopes of Mt Agung, represents a mental quandary for the conservationist. Called the mother temple of the Shaivite Hindu religion, Pura Besakih is not one structure but a cluster of structures dedicated to the Trimurti: Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva. Around the main temple are clan temples and other smaller temples. At present, a new temple is being built by the silver and goldsmiths’s guild. The new temple promises to be more sumptuous than the older ones. Older temples are renewed; their roofs of palm fiber and woodwork changed regularly or when damaged by the elements. Although tour guides claim that Besakih was built in the 11th century, it is suspected to be older.

A study of the pre-1930s Balinese sculptures at the Bali Museum in Denpasar shows the difference between the historical periods. These statues are far removed from earlier pieces: they are simply delineated, and some even display only a few abstract strokes not the richly decorated, graceful carving we associate with Balinese stonework. Much of the decoration and statuary in Besakih belong to the ornate style we may want to call Balinese baroque, which we can trace to the art revival of the 1930s, inspired by the Europeans Walter Spies and Bonnet, working closely with the sultan of Ubud.

A move to conserve the Besakih temple, meaning to keep as much of the old stones and statuary in place, was met with opposition by the Balinese themselves. The focus of contention centered on the Balinese sense of architecture. For the Hindu Balinese, the one reality of life is its flux. Balinese rituals are all about passages and changes. The final ritual of life, cremation, is intended to return the human body back to the basic elements: earth, water, and fire. Analogically, architecture also has a life cycle; thus the periodic feasts to honor the gods and the spirits. The gods and the spirits do not dwell permanently in sacred sites, but come down through the throne-like towers where offerings of flowers, pandan, rice, coconut, food, and incense are laid, displayed on dainty plaited palm leaf trays. The temples are not alive in the same way all of the time. They are more “alive” at great feasts when it is customary to drape sacred figures and structures with checkered sarongs and precious cloths. This living architectural structure, like all things on earth, decay. For the Balinese, the renewal of old things is an important element of religious belief. Thus, structures within temples are updated. The pavilions for preparing offerings are now decked with glazed tiles, when they may have been packed earth in earlier times. The shrines are embellished with statuary, churned in large quantities in Batubulan from soft sandstone, volcanic stone, even molded in cement. All depend on the devotion of the followers who believe that improving temples is a meritorious act.

What then does conservation mean for a culture that values flux and change over permanency as European Classicist culture does? The Yogyakarta and Kotagede declaration of 1996, describes heritage as encompassing a wider social phenomenon: “urban conservation involves enhancing the quality of life within the framework of the evolving built environment.” The focus must no longer be on the built environment apart from people, but the evolving environment, which must serve to enhance a people’s lives.

Clearly as the heritage conservation movement diffuses worldwide, the term itself can no longer hold a univocal meaning. Heritage has become a contested concept. When heritage professionals and advocates throughout Asia describe heritage conservation, they cite a range of things: from monuments and sites, to artifacts, to cultural performances, to habits and customs, to values of tribes, to literature.

The consequence of this equivocal or sliding definition of heritage means that the practice of heritage conservation is a variety of tasks. These can mean anything from the conservation and preservation of ancient and historic structures to the documentation of cultural performance through electronic media. It can also involve the revitalization and modernization of traditions or their careful transmission through a system of apprenticeship. It can also involve petrifying the tradition in museums and museum-like surroundings, as in the creation of heritage villages and zones. An extreme version of this petrification process is the Disney-fication of heritage conservation with heritage theme parks.

Like all movements, the heritage conservation has no single center, nor is there always consensus. Although international conservation organizations exist, these bodies serve principally as clearing houses or as facilitators. Part of UNESCO’s policy involves waiting for the national or local body to arrive at consensus before offering technical assistance. The inscription on the World Heritage List depends on the work on the local level, including adequate and reliable documentation, the setting up of conservation plans, and organization of local conservancy groups.

Because heritage is a sliding concept, private initiatives are equally varied. Some NGOs operate as lobbying bodies for legislation on the local and national level; others educate conservators in history, cultural appreciation, and the more technical tasks of conservation. Still, others center on cultural values embodied by heritage.

Heritage Conservation in the Philippines. A precursor to heritage conservation in the Philippines was Daniel H. Burnham’s response to the suggestion that the American government in the Philippines tear down the walls of Intramuros to allow traffic to flow more smoothly through Manila. In his 1905 proposal for an urban plan of Manila, Burnham proposed to retain Intramuros and keep it as intact as possible because of its historical and cultural value and build the new city of Manila around it. However, because it was infested with malarial mosquitos, the Bureau of Public Works, entrusted with the implementation of Burnham’s plan, decided to fill the Intramuros moat and convert it to a green space, which later became a golf course.

The destruction of the Philippines, especially of Manila, at the end of World War II was devastating. The reconstruction of Manila and the rest of the Philippines began with the conscious objective of immediate reconstruction of damaged buildings and structures, especially public ones, to make them serviceable again and allow the continuity of institutions. Rebuilding was necessary in order to return to normalcy, the rebuilding of the social order and economic recovery. Funds for rebuilding were managed through the War Damage Claims office, which distributed money to the public and private sectors. Funds also came from Japan as part of their war restitution. Government buildings were rebuilt following original plans, but in some cases were simplified. For instance, the elaborate ceiling of the Central Post Office in Manila was not reconstructed and the detached colonnade at the ends of the Legislative building was replaced by pilasters. Within a decade and a half, much had been rebuilt.

But many more buildings remained in ruins and were never rebuilt. For instance, from the 1950s to the 1960s, Intramuros remained abandoned as the religious orders moved their principal churches or houses elsewhere: the Dominicans, Franciscans, Jesuits, and Capuchins to Quezon City; the Recollects to San Sebastian in Quiapo; the brothers of San Juan de Dios to Pasay City.The University of Santo Tomas moved to the Sampaloc district.The Ateneo de Manila campus, which had moved out of Intramuros because of the 1932 fire, moved even further away from Ermita—all the way to Loyola Heights in Quezon City.The Colegio de Santa Isabel moved to Taft Ave while the Real Monasterio de Santa Clara moved to Quezon City, on a bluff overlooking Marikina Valley.Of the damaged churches, only the Manila Cathedral was rebuilt.Although it retained the Romanesque lines of its historic design, the interior and the decorative details were all new, the result of creative interaction between Filipino and Italian artists.The rebuilt cathedral was consecrated in 1958.

As for the rest of Intramuros, high-rise buildings, apartments, and commercial strips were built in utter disregard of the Spanish colonial style, which was still visible in spite of all the damage.The green area around the walls became a garbage dump and a bus terminal.The stones of the wall were quarried for new constructions, and Intramuros became the haven for the urban poor and a parking lot for cargo trucks and container vans because of its close proximity to the port.Streets and plazas were reconfigured into parking lots or fenced in.

Belatedly, the government issued guidelines in the 1950s that all rebuilding in Intramuros should be in the Spanish style of architecture, but did not specify what that meant. The seed of heritage conservation was planted and it started where building in stone began in the Philippines— Intramuros.

The National Historical Institute started working on restoring the walls with the help of civic groups and ad hoc committees; the most active of which were the Intramuros Restoration Committee and the Armed Forces Ladies’ Committee. In 1966, they repaired the gates and restored Fort Santiago’s moat and other structures, like the Fortín de San Francisco and the Bastión de Santa Lucia.

In 1979, the Intramuros Administration (IA) was created by Presidential Decree 1616 and placed under the Ministry of Human Settlements.The IA worked out a comprehensive plan regarding development and zoning of Intramuros.It built Casa Manila and a row of replica houses beside it, restored several plazas, particularly Plaza Roma and Plaza Sampalucan, Puerta Santa Lucia, and the revellin of Puerta del Parian.The IA continues to supervise Intramuros restoration.It is currently reconstructing the Church of San Ignacio, the original church of the Ateneo Municipal de Manila, which will be reused as a museum.

The restoration of the walls of Intramuros were an early laboratory of heritage conservation. The walls were repaired with a mixture of adobe, lime, and cement. During the Marcos presidency, which was from 1965 to 1986, the restoration of Intramuros and other heritage sites was supported by the government. Work was done on the San Agustin Church in Intramuros and the Santa Ana Church. In fact, a precolonial gravesite was discovered at Santa Ana, and excavated by the National Museum. In Batac, Ilocos Norte, the house where nationalist painter Juan Luna was born was rebuilt.

Synthetic adobe was developed in the 1970s, and initially used in the construction of domestic architecture that strove to look colonial. This consisted of crushed adobe mixed with cement and applied as a finish to walls. When the finish had dried, the smoothed surface of the wall was chipped to create the illusion of adobe. Often, while the wall was drying, grooves were cut into the surface to simulate the look of cut stone. This technology, which had been used for the walls of Intramuros, was also used to resurface the San Agustin and Santa Ana Churches. The popularity of synthetic adobe spread and became the common technique used in restoration. The long-term result was disastrous. The new layer formed a barrier that did not allow moisture to escape and caused more damage on the stone walls, which originally were finished with a soft lime plaster called palitada.

In a number of instances, where the palitada had degraded and exposed the stones or bricks, which was the structural core of a wall, many thought that these stones or bricks were the original surface of the wall. Because they looked antique and romantic, many architects and engineers removed the palitada. The effect was the rapid degradation of the structural material, because its barrier against the elements, especially waterproofing, had been removed. The result was a disaster. Walls started to leak and erode. Vegetation grew on the moist material and threatened to crack the stones.

In the 1970s and 1980s, there was a lack of research and information on historic architecture and technique of construction. There were a handful of professional restoration architects, who often worked on more modern projects as their main job and worked on restoration when need arose. There were almost no technicians and workers competent in working with historic buildings. On top of that, there was the gap in the knowledge of the general public about heritage sites and structures and their importance and significance. Hence, until the present, heritage conservation is plagued with controversies.

Continuing Controversies. The demolition of the iconic Jai Alai building in Manila on 15 Jul 2000 put the issue of heritage conservation in the Philippines into the spotlight. This case highlighted the desecration of the country’s heritage sites in the consciousness of the public. The heritage law prohibits anything that would impede the direct view of a heritage site or would introduce new materials incompatible to that of the old structure, affecting its integrity and authenticity, thus diminishing its value.

The Jai Alai fiasco was just the start of a string of issues concerning the plight of the nation’s built heritage. Other cases followed. The replacement of the wooden trusses of Laoag church by steel in 2003 to 2004 was met with stern opposition from heritage advocates, saying the added weight of the new steel structure will affect the stability of the church walls. In 2004, an adoration chapel was illegally constructed at the courtyard of the Taal Basilica. Nine years later, another illegal structure, this time a multipurpose hall, was constructed at the courtyard located at the left side of the church. The project was stopped by a court order issued in 2013 because it violated the heritage law.

Another important edifice which suffered the same fate as the Jai Alai building is the old Meralco building in San Marcelino St, Manila. The streamlined modern art deco structure designed by Juan Arellano, with the relief of Italian sculptor Francesco Monti titled The Furies, was completely demolished in 2013 to give way to a condominium project and a fast-food store.

Incorrect intervention approaches, poor maintenance, wanton disregard of the significance of the country’s important heritage structures coupled with ignorance or simply the defiance of the heritage law are just some of the reasons why heritage conservation remains a concern. The overlapping of tasks by government cultural agencies is also partly to be blamed.

The Paoay church restoration in Ilocos Norte in 2012 became controversial since the result, according to heritage advocates, was far from what was expected. What used to be a relief of a moon on one side of the facade is now a sun, copied from the sun relief on the other side. Some of its cornices, which used to be thin, are now thicker after the conservation works.

The ancestral houses on Vigan’s Mestizo district have earned praises for their conservation management programs, but the commercialization of the area made it more of a business district in recent years. Another example is the Las Casas Filipinas de Acuzar in Bagac, Bataan where ancestral houses from all over the Philippines are transplanted, piece by piece, to serve as restaurants, shops, events places, and suites. This case has caught the ire of heritage advocates who question the transfer of structures from their original sites, which lessen or erase their heritage value. This particular issue of transferring structures remains unanswered and needs more study and debate.

In Sep 2014, a series of heritage conservation issues hounded the City of Manila, starting with the controversial redevelopment project of the Army Navy Club building which reduced the historic edifice into a mere shell. The stripping of the building was done without a detailed engineering study as required by law. The National Historical Commission of the Philippines (NHCP) was forced to issue a cease-and-desist order against the developer, which was later lifted after the development plan submitted by the architectural firm hired by the developer was accepted by the NHCP. The developer also paid a penalty for violating the heritage law. This case was followed by the demolition of the Admiral Hotel on Roxas Blvd in Malate as well as the nearby Michel Apartments—both prewar buildings designed by well-known architects. Preceding these events was the controversy on the construction of the 49-story Torre de Manila condominium project near Taft Ave, which mars the vista of the iconic Rizal Monument in Luneta, a declared National Monument and a National Cultural Treasure. On 5 Jan 2015, the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) issued a cease-and-desist order against its developer, saying the project affects the physical integrity of the park and the monument.

Another heritage conservation issue was the National Museum project on Fort Pilar in Zamboanga City in 2014, when palitada was applied on the inner brick walls. The project attracted the ire of the locals who reacted to the modern appearance of the walls, which were in fact originally covered with palitada. The palitada’s removal was the result of neglect. Photographic evidence from the 1950s showed that all the buildings inside Fort Pilar had a layer of palitada and whitewash. Obviously, the degradation of the buildings’s walls was because of a lack of maintenance, which is much needed because the fort stands near the seashore, exposing it to seawater spray and wind. An earlier intervention outside the fort was able to renovate and embellish the Shrine of Nuestra Señora del Pilar. A permanent altar, a small chapel, and images of saints were mounted on a new perimeter wall. The shrine once attracted the Muslims who honored Mary as the mother of Jesus, but they have since shied away from it, possibly offended by the many statues on the perimeter fence. In 2014, also in Zamboanga, a faction of the Moro National Liberation Front invaded the city and a three-week siege ensued causing damage to the 19th-century Taluksangay Mosque as the Philippine military bombarded the occupied area.

Aside from the given examples, other man-made threats to heritage include fire, war, and natural calamities. The Oct 2013 earthquake and the subsequent supertyphoon Yolanda, international codename Haiyan, damaged or destroyed many churches in the Visayas, particularly in the island-province of Bohol, Cebu, Samar, and Leyte. National cultural as well as private agencies and individuals faced the difficult task of assessing the damage wrought on these religious edifices. The churches of Dimiao, Panglao, Baclayon, Cortes, Dauis, Loay, and Loboc were considered restorable. Most likely nonrestorable on their original sites are the churches of Maribojoc and Loon. Both in ruins, Maribojoc sits on a geological fault and Loon’s plateau or Ibabao is riddled with sinkholes. Old bridges and watchtowers in Bohol were also affected by the powerful quake, including the restored tower of Balilihan and the Fuerza de San Vicente Ferrer at Punta Cruz in Maribojoc. In the neighboring island of Cebu, the upper portion of the belfry of the Santo Niño Basilica collapsed. The church was closed to the public in the aftermath of the earthquake and was reopened only on 24 Dec 2014. Meanwhile, the church of Guiuan in Eastern Samar, which was destroyed by Yolanda in 2013, is undergoing reconstruction. The restoration and reconstruction of all damaged churches and important structures mentioned may take years to finish.

Natural disasters such as volcanic eruptions, floods, tsunamis, typhoons, and the resulting storm surges also pose a threat to heritage structures. In 1814, the violent eruption of the Mayon Volcano in Albay buried the then town of Cagsawa and destroyed the church. Today, only the belfry of the church remains standing above ground. The violent earthquake of 1863 sent the Manila Cathedral crashing to the ground, entombing the cathedral chapter and the many people who had gathered for evening prayers during the eve of Corpus Christi.

Similarly, strong earthquakes in 1863 and 1880 damaged churches and other structures in Manila and neighboring provinces. Another powerful earthquake in 1948 damaged and destroyed a number of churches in the province of Iloilo; the most notable of these is the neo-Gothic church of Oton, known for its Greek cross plan and central retablo that had a tall spire as center and four altars corresponding to the four arms of the cruciform plan. In 1983, churches and other structures in the Ilocos region were also affected by an earthquake. The church of Vintar was reconstructed as a result of that tremor.

In the mid-1990s, the church of Bacolor in Pampanga was half buried as a result of the lahar flow from the 1991 eruption of Pinatubo. Between two to three meters of lahar buried the Bacolor Church and other towns and villages along the Porac-Potrero River. The highway linking San Fernando and Olongapo, Zambales was covered with lahar and had to be raised and rebuilt. Over many years, floods threatened San Fernando and reached south to Minalin, because lahar had raised the ground level surrounding San Fernando.

In 2014, Typhoon Glenda, international codename Rammasun, damaged more than 30 heritage houses in Unisan, Quezon. These houses suffered varying damages on walls and roofs. The storm also damaged the town’s Spanish-era municipal hall. Tropical Storm Seniang, international codename Jangmi, the last weather disturbance to hit the Philippines in 2014, affected several provinces in Mindanao and Visayas, including the already earthquake-hit Bohol. The town of Loboc, including its church, was submerged by flood due to heavy rains.

Promising Developments. Three developments promise to boost the cause of heritage conservation in the Philippines. First is the growing awareness of the importance of heritage conservation seen in the establishment of the Heritage Conservation Society (HCS) in the Philippines, which was an initiative of the private sector. Established in Manila to serve as an advocacy group, HCS has given rise to similar heritage conservation groups outside Manila, like Iloilo and Cebu.

Supporting the work of HCS is the increasing number of publications regarding architecture in the Philippines. As scholars and writers go through archives and libraries, updated information has become available. Foreign scholars have also taken an interest in the Philippines. The internet has also facilitated the spread of information. Photographic archives of historical Philippine subjects from public repositories and individuals in the Philippines and abroad are now available online, enriching the data bank of anyone interested in heritage.

A second development is the training of the craftsmen and artisans who work in restoration. Escuela Taller, initially supported by the Spanish government, has brought in Mexican and Filipino masters to teach restoration technologies to students from the poor sectors of Metro Manila. Subjects on stonework, masonry, historic formulas of cement, decorative painting, and more mundane subjects like plumbing and electricity are taught. Its students are now beginning to make a difference in the proper restoration of heritage structures.

The third development is the more active participation of government agencies in the work of conservation. The NHCP has increased its output in placing historical and cultural markers on important structures and sites. It has also declared sites as historical, or as heritage corridors, like Dapitan. The NCCA, in cooperation with the National Museum of the Philippines, has declared some structures and artifacts as National Cultural Treasures or Important Cultural Properties. Such a declaration means that the government is bound to protect the property and can offer assistance should repair be called for. As culmination to the long effort to raise consciousness regarding the value of heritage, Republic Act No. 10066 National Cultural Heritage Act was signed into law in 2009.

A notable success in heritage conservation is the restoration of the Gota de Leche building, a neo-Renaissance structure that was completed in 1917 for an organization that fostered the health of women and children. It received honorable mention from the UNESCO Asia-Pacific Heritage Award for Cultural Heritage Conservation in 2003.

The art deco buildings of Far Eastern University were competently restored. In preparation for nomination as World Heritage Site, the palitada of San Agustin was restored. The destructive synthetic adobe was removed, replaced by soft lime plaster, following the formulas of the Spanish colonial era. Escuela Taller restored the Almacenes Reales in Intramuros and the building at the Bastion de Santa Barbara in Fort Santiago, Intramuros. The prewar houses in Pasay City have been reused as hotels, as exemplified by the Henry Hotel.

The provinces are not without their success stories. The Lopez Mansion, straddling the boundary of La Paz and Jaro in Iloilo, was restored to its former Streamline Moderne style. The declaration of Iloilo’s central business district as a heritage zone by the NHCP has spurred urban renewal and the cleaning and restoration of pre-World War II buildings, mostly in the neoclassical or art deco style. The arcaded side walk, a feature of Iloilo urban architecture, is being rediscovered as a practical solution to an island battered by heavy rain and intense summer heat.

The Department of Education, since the time of Corazon Aquino’s presidency from 1986 to 1992, has been restoring the Gabaldon school houses and the high school buildings constructed during the American era. The high school at Baguio City is exemplary because it follows all the recommendations of Burnham to build with sensitivity to the surroundings. The use of Baguio limestone as an accent, the green roof and white walls, blend in with the rocks, fog, and trees of Baguio City. With more awareness and enthusiasm for heritage conservation, the Philippines seems ready to preserve its own built heritage.  Written by René B. Javellana, with additional notes from Edgar Allan M. Sembrano

Manuals are handbooks written by architects, painters, and engineers to teach construction design and planning.

Indigenous Tradition

Very little is known on how building techniques were transferred through generations during the precolonial era. In the indigenous tradition, knowledge was handed down orally, or through practice. Anthropologists have surmised that in the indigenous tradition that survives to this day, vestiges of precolonial practice are still evident. However, whatever has remained unmodified in the course of time is uncertain.

Apprenticeship is the standard path where knowledge of construction, design, and planning is passed on. Often, the master is the head of a family and the apprentices are children and relatives. Some secrets may be guarded by families so that outsiders will not be able to copy what is being taught. Tools, patterns, or models are often passed on from generation to generation. In general, it is men who engage in the task of building dwellings and furniture for the house. For the Ifugao, the hagabi, or prestige bench of thekadangyanor the aristocratic class, involves rituals and feasting from the moment wood is procured from the forest to its carving and delivery to the kadangyan’s house. Thus, many shamans are also artisans.

Paete, Laguna is known for its carvers, many specializing in the sculpting of santos or saints’s images for churches and for home altar. Although its carving tradition is associated with the Spanish era, the techniques used may be older. The Paete tools are similar to other carving types across Southeast Asia. For instance, the mallet for carving is not the truncated Western cone, but a paddle, which is used also by indigenous groups in the Philippines. The Paete carver rarely uses a vise to steady a piece of wood, especially if the image being carved is below one meter. Instead, the wood block is fixed on a carving table and wedged to steady it. If Paete has preserved precolonial traditions, then its method of transmitting knowledge may point to a deeply rooted cultural practice. Here, woodcarvers are organized by families, where knowledge and skills, even a particular style of carving, are passed on from generation to generation. Even as a child, the Paeteño may work in his father’s talyer or shop. Starting with the simple task of sandpapering and carving, the child is told to copy simple models under the supervision of an adult. Eventually, as the child grows, more complex tasks are given, including doing the rough work for an image the master carver will finish. Analogously, the same may be said of the Ifugao carvers of the Cordillera. Among them, carving is traditionally not done for the sake of ornamentation only; it has religious significance and is accompanied by specific rituals.

Builders of the bahay kubo (nipa hut) have traditionally prescribed guidelines when to cut bamboo to prevent rot and insect infestation. This is usually done during the cold months of late November to February, when the bamboo has stopped growing and has hardened. “Taga sa panahon,” or “Cut at the proper time,” is the Tagalog adage for bamboo that is suitable for construction. Bamboo is cured by submerging it in water. Where the sea is close by, bamboo is immersed in salt water to cure it. The laying of the nipa or grass thatch is passed on orally or through the process of imitation. In Panay Island, nipa thatch is laid either tightly or loosely. The tighter and thicker thatch is more expensive because it uses more material and takes more time to build. The distance between thatches is determined using a matchbox. If the distance between the thatch is equivalent to the shorter side of the match box (nagahigda, literally “lying on its side”) or roughly 4 cm, this produces a tighter roof; if the distance is equivalent to the longer side of the match box (nagatindog, or “standing with the longer side up”) roughly 6 cm, this produces a looser thatch.

 

Spanish Colonial Era

Written manuals came during the Spanish colonial era. They assumed a culture where writing had replaced oral instruction. Manuals were also a convenient way to transfer knowledge beyond the talyer to a wider audience. The appearance and proliferation of the architectural manual in Renaissance Europe was facilitated by the advent of the movable type printing press. Manuals were written and copied by friars and engineers, who drew from field experience and from the locals themselves, but only a few of these have survived. Published books and journal articles brought into the country enriched the archives.

The foundation of towns in Spanish overseas colonies was prescribed among other things in the Leyes de Indias (Laws of the Indies) decreed by Philip II on 3 Jul 1575 (Lico 2008, 110-13). The site chosen for a settlement should be vacant or otherwise should not be occupied without the free consent of the natives. It should be elevated, rich in resources, and have enough area for future development. Detailed instructions were given on the laying out of streets according to a cuadricula or grid plan. The starting point for the building of the town was the plaza. In inland towns, it was to be in the middle, its length at least one and a half times its width because this proportion was the best for festivals when horses were used. First place was to be given to the local church, which should occupy a whole block. In inland towns, the church was to be some distance from the plaza and separate from other buildings so it could be visible from all sides. Next would be the Royal and Town Council House, the Customs House, arsenal, and hospital for the poor and sick of noncontagious diseases. None of these was to obstruct the view of the church.

Drawing from the Mediterranean experience, the streets needed to be narrow. The four corners of the plaza were to face the four compass points, so that the streets would not be directly exposed to the four principal winds. This was the case in Intramuros, where one side of the street enjoyed some shade at most times of the day.

A town near a seaport was to have its plaza and main church near the landing place, with the church clearly visible and strong enough to serve as a defense. Though not quite observable today, this plan was followed by Vigan City. When the river was still navigable, boats landed at the foot of the Vigan plateau, and people ascended a series of steps leading to the cathedral plaza. These steps still exist today.

 

The Leyes codified much of what had already been practiced in classic Mediterranean planning, as enunciated by the Roman architect Vitruvius and the Italian Renaissance architect Leon Battista Alberti. Manila was laid out along a grid before the Leyes had been promulgated. Additionally, this revival of the grid-plaza complex became popular in key Spanish cities like Madrid and Salamanca only in the 18th century.

The Prevenciones y Disposiciones para Fabrica de Casa Nueba (Preventions and Provisions for the Construction of a New House) is a 50-page, incomplete, anonymous, and undated architectural manual found in the Dominican archives in the University of Santo Tomas (UST). From details in the text, it seems to have been written by an Augustinian based in San Agustin, Intramuros. For scale and measurements, constant reference was made to a large house on No 136 behind the Misericordia and the two others next to it. If the Misericordia referred to the hospital run the Hospitallers of San Juan de Dios in 1656, the manuscript is early indeed. However, the copy at UST seems to have been prepared in the 18th century.

 

The Prevenciones provide exquisitely detailed advice on the sources, transport, selection, preparation, installation, and maintenance of the various types of lumber and masonry to be used in a building. The pillars, trusses, and other wooden components of a house are individually described and prescribed, including baraquilos and baratexas, boncalos, canales maestras, llaves, pilares and pilaretes, quilos and sobrequilos, soleras, tablas, tablasuelos, tajilanes, tirantes, and trozos. The best molave pillars were sourced from San Miguel, Bulacan; the horizontal beams had to be of betis or pasac, sourced from Lubao, Gapan, or Arayat. Rafts of these logs were floated down Laguna de Bay or Mariveles during the dry months following February. The logs had to be stripped of the termite-attracting bark called banacal before being thoroughly dried. These were worked and processed into lumber which resembled bars of soap and were called jabonados.

Large stone blocks called sillares were used for facades and arches, while smaller blocks, or sillaretes, were used to frame windows. Slightly thinner blocks called tablillas de ciudad were meant for walls, while tablillasordinarias were laid on pavements. The best stone came from Meycauayan, Bulacan, which was superior to that from Guadalupe or San Juan del Monte nearer Manila. The mortar was to flow into all the spaces between the gravel in the foundations, or in between walls, and was to be poured in after every layer of gravel. Gravel and sand had to be washed thoroughly so that no salt was left; beach sand was to be avoided. To strengthen the mortar (which was called lechada or mezcla ), a little molasses (miel de caña) was added. The palitada had to be applied when the walls were wet, and inner walls had to be applied thinly, and then polished. To strengthen the foundation and walls against earthquakes, a sillar or tablilla was half embedded in the rubble layer, to act as an anchor for the next layer (Jose 2003).

 

Another manual that became popular during the Spanish colonial period was written by a priest. After building the church of Santo Niño in Cebu from 1735 to 1740, Fr Juan Albarran, OSA, wrote down his experiences and advice in an 18-page manuscript now preserved in the Augustinian Archives in Valladolid, Spain. Entitled Advertencias para Obras que se Puedan Ofrecer en Este Convento, (Annoucements of Works that May Be Offered in This Convent) the work provides detailed instructions on the components and construction of walls, openings, supports, and roofs. Albarran manifests knowledge of Andrea Palladio’s First Book of Architecture (translated into Spanish in 1570), Fray Lorenzo de San Nicolas’s Arte y Uso de Arquitectura (Art and Use of Architecture), 1639-64, Juan de Arfe’s De Varia Conmensuracion (Of Various Commensuration), 1587, and Juan Bautista de Villapando’s Tratado de la Arquitectura Perfecta (Treaty of Perfect Architecture), 1604. Some of his procedures echo those from classic works: the preparation of lime for the mortar is similar to that recommended by the Renaissance theoretician Leon Battista Alberti.

Lime could be obtained not just from the rocks called manongol, but from other white outcrops in the area, even from the gravel used as filling (piedra vitoca or cascaxo) in the walls. The limestone was to be chopped into bits to be cooked in a lime kiln or calero; the firewood was to equal the stone to be cooked. The island of Mactan was an ideal source for cut stone or tablillas, filling, and lime. Black sand was preferred to white, and had to be washed thoroughly so that salt, which absorbed water, or earth, which contained the seeds of plants, could be eliminated. Lime quarried from the mountain needed one more part sand, compared to the two parts required for one part lime from the beach. However, it was still best to experiment with different proportions to obtain the proper mixture.

Ideally, walls of cut stone were to have two rows of stone blocks alternate with one laid perpendicularly. Because this was difficult to achieve in Cebu, an alternative was to have large stones laid within the walls to anchor the layers above.

Father Albarran provided careful diagrams for the computations of arches and roof trusses. A round or medio-punto arch was derived from a circle; an oblong arch or carpanelo maior was obtained from two overlapping circles; while a low oblong arch, carpanelo menor or rebajado was drawn from the arcs of three circles. The cuadrado, or square, of one braza by one braza (approximately one yard by one yard) was recommended as the simple basis of proportion for the expanse and height of walls and facades .

In addition, the Dominicans in Pangasinan were known to have written “Modo de teñir madera” (method of staining wood), “Modo de hacer ladrillos” (methods of brick-making), and “Modo de soldar hierro” (method of soldering iron), but none of these works have been located.

Aside from these manuals, little more than a handful of published treatises on architecture has been found in colonial-era libraries. In UST, there are preserved works by Serlio, 1566; Arfe, 1675; Pozzo, 1693; Derand, 1755; an anonymous treatise on the work of Sulzer and Mengs, 1786; and Vitruvius, 1787. An especially rare find is Dominguez Zamudio’s Theses Mathematicas printed in Manila in 1766.

Sebastiano Serlio’s D’Architettura, 1566, presents in five well-illustrated chapters geometry, perspective, the great buildings of Rome, the five orders of architecture, and plans of palaces and churches. A 1675 Madrid edition of Juan de Arfe y Villafañe’s Varia Conmensuracion para la Escultura y Arquitectura (Various Conmensuration for Sculpture and Architecture) was owned by the Filipino sculptor Isabelo Tampinco. It passed on to the art collector Alfonso T. Ongpin, whose granddaughter Cynthia O. Valdes then donated the book to the UST Library. Arfe divides his Varia into four books that deal with geometry, the drawing of the human figure, the drawing of animals, and the proportions of architecture and ecclesiastical objects. How the Varia came into the possession of Tampinco is unknown, though the book’s 300 diagrams could very well have influenced its readers.

Perspectiva Pictorum et Architectorum, published in 1693 by Andrea Pozzo, SJ, is a large-format book (about the size of a tabloid newspaper) composed of 100 annotated plates featuring architectural details and plans. This book, by the 17th-century baroque painter of the frescoes in San Ignazio, Rome, belonged to the Colegio de San Ignacio in Manila. L’Architecture des Voutes ou L’Art des Traits et Coupes des Voutes published in 1755 by Francois Derand, the Jesuit librarian of the Sorbonne, demonstrates the calculation for arches and vaults in several illustrations.

The anonymous, Dell’Arte di Vedere nelle Belle arti del Disegno Secondo i Principi de Sulzer, e di Mengs, 1786, does not have illustrations but has a chapter on the visual appreciation of buildings according to the principles of Sulzer and Mengs. The buildings selected were all from Rome, such as the Colosseum, Saint Peter’s, Sant’Andrea della Valle, and the Farnese Palace. A sumptuous Spanish edition of Marcus Vitruvius’s Los Diez Libros de Architectura (Ten Books of Architecture), from 1787, is another tabloid-sized treasure. The 277 pages are complemented by 56 plates engraved from drawings by Joseph Ortiz y Sanz, a priest who translated the work from Latin. Los Diez Libros is composed of 10 chapters that deal with a wide range of topics: the selection of sites; building materials; types of temples; the three types of columns; public buildings; domestic buildings; wall finishings; water and fountains; astronomy and clocks; and machines.

Of great interest is the Theses Mathematicas, defended by Juan Dominguez Zamudio in the Colegio de San Ignacio in Manila and printed by Nicolas de la Cruz Bagay in the Jesuit press in Intramuros in 1766. This is a treatise on fortification which, coming just two years after the British occupation of Manila, was particularly timely, if not a bit too late. Its 38 pages contain 19 theses, each divided into a number of resolutions. Theses One to Ten deal with munitoria, or military architecture. The parts of a fort are described, with recommended measurements and geometrical proportions for each. Theses Eleven to Seventeen deal with pyrotechnia, or the art of casting and using cannon. In the last two Theses, the defense or siege of a fortified settlement is discussed. The work is illustrated with foldout copperplate engravings by Cipriano de la Cruz Bagay.

The 1766 Theses Mathematicas forms one of a largely unknown type of scientific literature that involved aspects of architecture. As shown in a recent study, the teaching of mathematics in Manila contributed to a more rational basis for building technology. Similarly titled Theses, this appeared in 1758, 1761, and 1762; all were connected with the Jesuit Colegio de San Ignacio.

An inventory of the sequestered library of the Jesuit Colegio de San Ignacio indicates that it had a copy of Giacomo Barozzi da Vignola’s Regoli delli Cinque Ordini A’architettura, first published in 1562, probably in Rome. Da Vignola was the architect of Il Gesu, the Jesuit mother church in Rome.

The architecture discipline had another hurdle to overcome in the Philippines—natural disasters. The earthquake that shook Luzon on 3 Jun 1863 forced the review and reform of building techniques, especially by engineers. After the earthquakes on 18 and 20 Jul 1880 it was noticed that post-1863 buildings repaired or built under government direction suffered relatively less damage than private buildings. Such constructions included the Puente de España, the Cathedral, San Juan de Dios Hospital, and the Aduana, all in Manila.

An official telegram from Madrid on 21 Jul 1880 mandated the Manila government to formulate a plan and technical conditions for the construction of public and private buildings. A set of recommendations by the General Inspection of Public Works was discussed by an ad hoc Consultative Board of Public Works which met in extraordinary session on 27-29 Jul. The recommendations were drawn from assessments of earthquake damage and from data published by the Manila Observatory.

On 30 Jul 1880 the Board released 27 prescriptions: nine of a general nature; five on the liabilities of carpentry; six for woodwork; and seven for masonry. The Board was headed by Manuel Ramirez Bazan, who was the Inspector General of Public Works. It included Eduardo Lopez Navarro, principal discussant and builder of the neo-Romanesque Manila Cathedral and of Manila’s new port system; Genaro Palacios, builder of Manila’s water system and of San Sebastian church; Manuel Lopez Bayo, who developed the wharf along the Pasig; Antonio de la Cámara, who drew plans for the Tabacalera of Binondo; Jose Centeno y Garcia, an expert on mines; and Luis Cespedes, who reformed the Aduana. Except for Cespedes, an architect, the rest were engineers.

On 16 Aug 1880 the General Inspection of Public Works approved 43 principal rules in the construction or repair of public and private buildings in the Philippines. These concerned location, foundations, cementing of parts, proportions of walls of mamposteria or rubblework masonry, buttresses, new additions to old buildings, ceilings, frameworks and their reinforcement, brick walls with frameworks, roofing, and balconies.

Foundations were to be presupposed to carry twice the weight of the building they would receive. The more homogenous the masonry was, the more resistant it was to earthquakes. The following were also the systems of construction in order of preference: concrete (hormigon) whether hydraulic or ordinary; brickwork; cut stone with ribs of brick; and cut stone (sillarejo and silleria). Materials with different elasticities were to be avoided. Frameworks of iron or wood could be faced with the artificial stone known as Victoria Stone that allows cooling air to flow through the interstices. Means of access had to be provided so that the frameworks could be regularly examined. Recommended materials for roofing were flat tiles, galvanized iron, zinc, tin, or similar incombustible material, taking care that there would be sufficient passage for ventilation but not of rainwater. Single-story constructions could be covered with azoteas in the style of Cadiz. Ordinary V-shaped tiles were restricted to isolated single-story buildings not meant for habitation, such as storehouses or warehouses. Existing tiles on buildings could be retained only if they were proven stable and if there was a sufficiently protective wooden ceiling.

The qualities of wood were noted. Only molave and ipil were resistant enough to be brought into direct contact with masonry. Molave was the only wood that could be exposed to the elements, covered with pitch or painted with oil. Floor beams were not to be embedded in the walls but had to rest on interlinked molave. Beams ofyakalfrom Angat were unsurpassable in their resistance to flexing.

Certain bad practices were castigated, such as supporting badly cut stone on slivers or calzos; disorderly insertion of rocks in between rows of cut stones; not keeping the materials moist enough before setting them; using salt water in the mortar; using poorly cooked or carbonated lime (if a few drops of acid elicited bubbles from the lime, it had to be rejected); poorly strained mortar; and improper priming of cut stones. The dividing walls called tabique pampango were absolutely forbidden, and had to be replaced with walls of metal plates or thin wooden planks.

On 18 Aug 1880 Gov-Gen Primo de Rivera forwarded these 43 rules to the Spanish Overseas Ministry, accompanied by a set of 18 managerial instructions. All public buildings to be constructed or repaired were first to have their plans, systems of construction, and the budget approved by the General Inspection of Public Works. Before being occupied, a house had to be inspected by the municipal architect who would check its soundness. As soon as possible, all edifices damaged by the recent earthquakes were to be assessed by competent authorities and classified accordingly as: 1) in good condition; 2) in good condition but with specified repairs; 3) dangerous; and 4) ruined. The last two categories carried corresponding plans of action.

The 43 rules and 18 instructions, collectively called the “Earth quake Ordinances” were promulgated by Primo de Rivera on the 20 Aug 1880 edition of the Gaceta de Manila. All materials necessary for building in iron, and such parts for roofing as sand, galvanized iron and zinc sheets, and screws were exempted from customs duties.

Towards the last few years of the Spanish colonial era, Manuel Cortes y Argullo, a military engineer, published a two-volume work, Los Terremotos: sus Efectos en las Edificaciones y Medios Practicos para Evitarlos en lo Posible (Earthquakes: Their Effects on Buildings and Practical Guidelines to Minimize These as far as Possible), in Manila in 1881. The manuscript was originally prepared in 1873 but revised after the 1880 earthquake. Another military engineer, Manuel Herbella y Perez, wrote Manual de Construcciones y Fortificacion de Campañas en Filipinas in Madrid in 1882. Intended for constructions that would accompany military campaigns, especially in Mindanao, it is an important source for building technology in the Philippines.

Another engineer, Rafael Cerero y Saenz, was a high official of the Corps of Military Engineers who built military barracks in Mindanao in the 1880s. His plan to fortify Manila, if it had been carried out, could have changed the outcome of the Battle of Manila with the Americans. His Estudio Sobre la Resistencia y Estabilidad de los Edificios Sometidos a Huracanes y Terremotos or “A Study on the Resistance and Stability of Buildings Subjected to Hurricanes and Earthquakes” was written in Manila in 1889 and published in Madrid in 1890. He drew on his own experiences in the field, as well as from copious data shared by Fr Federico Faura, SJ, who was the Director of the Manila Observatory. He also makes references to materials from the Smithsonian Institute and from scholarly institutions in London, Paris, Rome, Berlin, and Tokyo, which gives us a glimpse of the breadth and depth of the library of the Corps of Engineers in Manila.

Cerero provides detailed recommendations on the construction of buildings given the propensity of the Philippines to experience natural disasters. Complicated equations provide the proper specifications for height, width, and depth of various parts of the house. The best model was still an edifice with a ground story of masonry and an upper one of wood, provided it was well-anchored. It had a multiplicity of joints that were perfectly joined, and it swayed “like an inverted pendulum” during earthquakes. Tall structures should not be attached to lower buildings because they had different resonation arcs.

The works of the last two decades of the 19th century give a picture of the introduction of modern materials for construction. There was Portland cement, used in the reconstruction of Manila Cathedral from 1872 to 1879. Also available in Manila markets were pozzolana cement, flat-glazed roof tiles, iron fittings from the United States (US), and Victoria Stone from Australia. Iron was specially recommended by builders. It had already been recommended for the Manila Cathedral in 1872 but was modified to molave sheathed in iron. An offshore lighthouse in San Nicolas, Tondo, was planned to be made of iron in 1876 by Jose Echevarria. The Earthquake Ordinances preferred rigid frameworks of iron for public edifices, especially if they were meant to contain large numbers of people, such as churches. They were only to be substituted with wood if the cost is impractical. Lintels were to be supported on iron or wood. Ceilings were to be of hollow voussoirs or dovelas of baked clay embedded in iron bars.

Architectural manuals were very useful in the Spanish colonial era when professional architects and engineers were scarce. But by the turn of the 19th century, more professional architects and engineers were arriving from Spain. One such Spanish architect was Juan Jose Hervas, who had flourishing career from 1855 to 1893 in Manila. With the opening of the Suez Canal in Nov 1869, travel between the Philippines and Europe was considerably cut short and some Filipinos were able to study in European schools. After completing their studies, they returned to the Philippines to practice their profession. Such was Felix Roxas, who left the Philippines in 1840 and spent more than a decade in Europe. He studied at Real Academia de Notables Artes de San Fernando, Madrid. He returned to Manila in 1854 to practice architecture.

American Colonial Era

Among the aims of American colonial rule was to construct a colony reflective of the philosophy and aims of American colonization. The Americans introduced modern methods of construction and systematized construction through the Bureau of Public Works and a system of licensing and evaluation by the municipal bureaucracy. They promoted the use of material and building techniques like new reinforced concrete using hydraulic cement, popularly known as Portland cement, and reinforcing steel bars.

Architectural manuals were effective in disseminating knowledge and kept up with the aggressive building program pursued by the American colonial government. This program followed a four-fold path. First, the Bureau of Public Works was organized to oversee the construction of public buildings like city and town halls, schools, markets, and hospitals. Second, with the establishment of the Bureau standard, plans for schools, military barracks, and other public buildings were drawn up. These plans guided the development of public structures but because government architects were allowed to develop a private practice, these structures would have a strong influence on the rest of architecture. Third, Filipinos were sent aspensionadosor scholars to study in the universities in the United States. After completing their studies, the pensionados usually worked with the Bureau but were also allowed to keep a private professional practice. Fourth, trade schools were organized in many provincial centers under the Bureau of Education. The linchpin of this system was the Philippine School of Arts and Trade, now the Technological University of the Philippines (TUCP) on Ayala Blvd and San Marcelino St in Manila. Industrial education was emphasized in the primary and secondary schools curriculum, and talented students were encouraged to enroll in the provincial trade schools or in the main school in Manila. Private schools that specialized in architecture were also permitted to operate.

Initially, upon the arrival of the Americans, public works was assumed by the Department of War. In 1902, with the establishment of civil rule, the Bureau of Engineering and Construction of Public Works and the Bureau of Architecture and Construction of Public Buildings were created by Philippine Commission Act Nos 22 and 268. The Bureau was placed under the Department of Commerce and Police and continued to remain under the department until 1916, when it was reorganized as the Department of Commerce and Communications, following Reorganization Act No 2666. When the Philippine Legislature met in 1931, the Department was renamed Department of Public Works and Communications (DPWC).

The Bureau of Public Works set the stage for the development of architecture and the transmission of knowledge through master plans for sanitation and health, city planning and infrastructure development, and the construction of public buildings: government centers, hospitals and clinics, and schools. On 15 Aug 1898, public works was placed under the US Army Corps of Engineers during the military government under Gen Arthur MacArthur. The first priority was to build military forts in Luzon and Cebu. Harry Allyn, the supervising architect, designed wooden barracks in Fort McKinley in the style of Swiss chalets. Plans were drawn to guide future construction.

The Bureau of Health, another participant in the development of architecture, with the assistance of the Bureau of Public Works, drew up plans for small detached houses, with a bath and veranda. They also designed the Antipolo latrine and a plan for a sanitary barrio to foster health and sanitation.

In 1912, William Parsons designed the prototypes for the public school buildings all over the Philippines, funded by the Philippine Assembly for one million pesos. Isauro Gabaldon, a member of the Philippine Assembly, authored the bill, so the school buildings were identified with him. The plans were published by the Bureau of Education in 1912 as Bulletin No 37, School Buildings and School Grounds.

More architects were trained through study. The initative of sendingpensionadosor scholars to study in the United States was part of the colonial plan. Among these pensionados were Juan Arellano and Antonio Mañalac Toledo. After graduating, these pensionados joined the Bureau of Public Works. Tomas Mapua, Juan Nakpil, and Fernando Ocampo were among the leading architects who worked for the Bureau.

In the Philippines, the establishment of trade schools was supported by the monthly periodical, The Philippine Craftsman, published by the Bureau of Education. It was addressed to teachers, as indicated by its subtitle: “A magazine published in Manila by the Bureau of Education devoted to the advancement of industrial instruction in the Public Schools of the Philippines.” The magazine carried a variety of articles, including documentation of traditional basketry; reports on crafts from other countries, like lace making in Europe; experiments on introducing new craft and skills; woodworking and other building skills. American scholar Alfred McCoy writes: “From 1912 to 1917, the bureau [of education] published a glossy, illustration-filled monthly magazine called the Philippine Craftsman, which was intended to keep teachers abreast of the progress of industrial education. Each issue included at least half a dozen substantive articles relevant to the work being done in the classrooms—studies of individual handicrafts in the Philippines, discussing gardening techniques and furniture making, and countless pieces” (McCoy 1995, 155).

Privately run architectural schools were also established and given a government license to operate. One of the most notable predecessors to modern architectural schools was Liceo de Manila, founded 1900, which opened an architecture program in 1902. Liceo ceased to exist in 1912. Tomas Mapua, after working for the Bureau of Public Works, established Mapua Institute of Technology in 1925. It was known for producing civil engineers who were important team members in any construction. The University of Santo Tomas followed in 1930 and Adamson University in 1941. The University of the Philippines (UP) also proposed a course in architecture but was turned down in 1928. Architecture in UP was not established until 1956.

The American era worked on the model of a highly organized architecture profession, supported by civil engineers, and competent craftsmen, supervised and controlled by a bureau which provided the dissemination and promotion of architecture as suited to the environment, and taking advantage of developments in material and building technology. University-trained architects and engineers who planned and supervised construction had a well-trained technical staff to realize their plans.

The level of training depended on where the technicians had trained. Those who went to the schools of arts and trades usually landed a higher position, like that of a supervisor, than those who had finished only basic education. Thus, during the American era, a plan was created to teach construction and crafts skills, not through manuals alone, but through engagement in the work under the supervision of teachers and trained technicians. Within four decades, the American colonial government had accomplished so much that it steered the development of architecture toward modern styles and methods but remained sensitive to the tropical surroundings of the Philippines and its cultural and architectural legacy. The grand plan was not fully realized and came to a halt when World War II erupted in 1941.

Period of the Republics

The American colonial era set the trajectory for the postwar transmission of architectural knowledge. While the DPWC ceased to function during the Japanese occupation, it reopened in 1946, despite constraints due to limited human resources, funds, materials, and equipment.

The immediate postwar period faced the task of reconstruction and modernization. In 1951, DPWC was reconstituted as the Department of Public Works, Transportation, and Communications (DPWTC). As an expanded department, it took charge of telecommunications, motor vehicles, irrigation, flood control, the Radio Control Board, the National Transportation Board, and the Government Quarters Committee. In 1972, the department was reorganized following the program set during the Martial Law era. With the adoption of a revised constitution in 1979, the department came to be known as a ministry. In the post-Marcos era, Executive Order No 123, of 30 Jan 1987 reorganized the ministry and it was now known as Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH). The functions of this department are analogous to those prevailing during the American era, particularly overseeing public construction. Increasingly, DPWH has contracted construction out to private companies, maintaining a supervisory role for itself.

Just as the DPWH descends directly from the Bureau, the system of architectural education on tertiary level builds directly on the educational system of the American era after World War II. The schools of arts and trades were reopened, but gradually the lure of technical jobs diminished. These schools devoted to arts and crafts evolved into universities offering a variety of academic fields like liberal arts, fine arts, and science, alongside the technical and technological courses like engineering, industrial technology, and industrial education.

Building codes in the Philippines can be traced back to the 19th century such as the Earthquake Ordinances promulgated by Gov-Gen Primo de Rivera in the 20 Aug 1880 edition of the Gaceta de Manila .These ordinances are the forerunner of the 1972 Republic Act No 6541, known as the National Building Code. While the Building Code does not give any specifications about the aesthetics of design, the Code’s intent being to safeguard public safety, the prescriptions and restrictions of the code are guidelines that sound design should base itself on.

In the 21st century, because of advances in architectural theory, concept, and design, supported by advances in engineering and the development of new material, a single architectural manual is no longer viable as a response to the demands of contemporary architecture and construction. However, the straightforward architectural manual of the Spanish era serves as a useful guide for those engaged in heritage conservation. Written by Regalado Trota Jose, with additional notes from René B. Javellana

Organizations are established by architects in order to promote unity and cooperation among themselves and to work for the development and upgrading of the profession and the welfare of its practitioners. The Academia de Arquitectura y Agrimensura de Filipinas, founded in 1902, was the first professional organization for those engaged in the practice of architecture, civil engineering, and surveying. In 1903, it was renamed Academia de Ingenieria, Arquitectura y Agrimensura de Filipinas. It founded the first school of architecture in the Philippines. In 1911, the engineers withdrew to form their own organization.

Because of the growing number of architects, the Philippine Architects Society was organized in 1933 under the initiative of Juan F. Nakpil. The first officers of the Society were Juan F. Nakpil as president, Tomas Mapua as vice president, Harold H. Keys as secretary-treasurer, and Sidney D. Rowlands and Fernando Ocampo as directors. Among its early accomplishments were the drafting of its Constitutions and By-Laws, the Rules of Charges and Professional Fees, and the Canon of Ethics of the Society. One of the aims of the Society was to seek the passage of a law that would protect the architectural profession.

In 1938, the Society was renamed Philippine Institute of Architects and Planners, and subsequently Philippine Institute of Architects or PIA. In 1946, the PIA held its first annual convention.

 

In 1950, about 15 members left the Institute and formed the League of Philippine Architects or LPA. On 17 Jun 1950, the architectural profession received its first separate statute with the enactment of Republic Act No 545, “An Act to Regulate the Practice of Architecture in the Philippines.” In 1955, the Boards of the Institute and the League met to discuss the merger of the organizations, but with no result. In 1957, the PIA was admitted as an affiliate organization of the Union Internationale des Architects (UIA). The PIA College of Fellows was created in 1972. In 1958, architects working in the government formed the Association of Philippine Government Architects or APGA.

In 1965, the PIA, LPA, and APGA passed resolutions approving the Architect’s National Code and the Architects’s Services and Schedule of Fees, which had been prepared by the PIA. Negotiations for the merger of the three organizations continued, but was ultimately fruitless.

 

Presidential Decree No 233, issued by Ferdinand Marcos in 1973, compelled the three organizations to be integrated as the United Architects of the Philippines (UAP). A negotiation panel was formed in May 1973. A 15-member ad hoc Commission was created to prepare the Constitution and By-Laws of UAP as a newly integrated association. On 12 Dec 1974 the Boards of PIA, LPA, and APGA approved the Constitutions and By-Laws of the UAP. In 1975, the Professional Regulation Commission certified the accreditation of the UAP as the only accredited professional organization for architects in the Philippines. An interim board was appointed to administer, implement, and monitor the activities of UAP until such time as a regular Board of Directors and Officers would be elected. There was a total of 1,300 members at the start of the UAP, and 700 more were registered as active members after its first year. On 26 Mar 1976, the UAP was registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The National Regulatory Board listed the UAP as the duly accredited architectural organization for architects in the Philippines.

 

The UAP aims to promote the highest standards of ethical conduct and excellence in the practice and service of the architectural profession as well as lifting of the standards of architectural education. The UAP is also committed to unify all registered architects of the Philippines through cooperation and coordination with allied professions, local and international trade and industry, participation in national development programs, and cooperation with the board of architecture and other government agencies. It is willing to render any lawful and appropriate assistance to any of its members.

On 12 Jun 1976, the UAP, which by law had become the only accredited architectural association in the Philippines, informed UIA of the status of all architectural organizations in the country. During the meeting of the UIA Council at Santiago de Chile from 24-26 Jan 1983, UIA passed Resolution No 9, in which UAP legally became the National Section of UIA.

UAP is one of the founding members of the Architects Regional Council of Asia (ARCASIA), organized in 1979, which is composed of organizations of architects from Singapore, Malaysia, Hongkong, Thailand, Indonesia, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Bangladesh, India, and the Philippines. The first Asian Congress of Architects was sponsored by ARCASIA and held in Manila in Oct 1984. The sixth conference was also held in Manila in Dec 1994.

Currently, UAP is organized into three areas: Area A, comprising northern and central Luzon and Metro Manila with five regional districts; Area B, comprising southern Luzon, the islands of Mindoro, Masbate, and Palawan, with five regional districts; and Area C, comprising the Visayas and Mindanao, with four regional districts.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III, updated by René B.Javellana
