Sections

General Surveys
Indigenous Tradition and Transformation
Hispanic Tradition and Transformation
American Colonial Tradition
The Period of the Republics

This essay is organized thematically and historically. It begins with a survey of general works on Philippine architecture, and then deals with the indigenous tradition, Hispanic tradition, American tradition, and their influences and transformations in the contemporary period. Within this broad historical framework, this essay deals with forms and major works associated with the historical period and the architects and builders who were active during the era. Because research is uneven and has many gaps, some sections are shorter than others and not subdivided, but others are.

Interest in the Philippines is not limited to Filipino scholars but extends to a substantial number of Spanish and Mexican scholars focusing in particular on Philippine colonial architecture of the Hispanic tradition. Specialized publications connected with exhibitions are placed at the end of the relevant section. Grouping the catalogue with a discussion on the exhibit gives it context.

 

General Surveys

Research on Philippine architecture during the first half of the 20th century was understandably limited to architecture strongly influenced by Western tradition. Perhaps, the very first overview of Philippine architecture is found in El Archipielago Filipino (The Philippine Archipelago), a two-volume compendium of facts about the Philippines compiled by the professors and teachers of the Ateneo Municipal de Manila and published in the United States (US) in 1900. These books are extensively quoted, almost verbatim, by the Report to the Philippine Commission of 1901. The section on architecture merely translates passages from El Archipielago. In brief, the section argued that great works of architecture were generally lacking in the Philippines and came only lately to the islands because the era of Spanish colonization corresponded to the era of bad artistic taste in Spain. The architectural section, probably written by Fr. Clotet, SJ, praised the neoclassical and revivalist architecture that had recently appeared in the country.

The bias for neoclassicism is reflected in Morilla Maria Norton’s Studies in Philippine Architecture, published around 1911, which could only look forward to better times when the US would ameliorate architecture in its new colony. She cites only two distinguished architects of the Spanish era: Felix Roxas Sr, who created neoclassical and neo-Gothic works; and Juan Hervas, who, according to Norton, introduced Catalan architecture.

Our Islands and its Peoples, a hefty tome in folio size, was a picture book on the Philippines, Cuba, Puerto Rico, and Hawaii. Written for popular consumption, the book is a survey premised on the attitude that nothing is good unless it comes from the US. A clearly biased account, the book disparages Hispanic architecture in the Philippines and calls all of it medieval and backward. The book had no intention of presenting architectural history; it was a polemical statement intended to bolster America’s hold on her colonies.

Very little was written about Philippine architecture during the first half of the 20th century, although articles on churches were published in magazines like Cultura Social. Around 1914, the anti-pornography league of San Francisco published the periodical magazine , and among the articles were surveys of colonial churches, notably those of the Augustinians, and notices of newly built churches. Aside from these, articles about artists and photographic features showing church art were published. The magazine was in Spanish and obviously meant for an older generation, and not for the younger generation, who were educated in the English language. The articles may have been motivated by nostalgia or polemical intent to rebut the insinuations of other writers that nothing of note came out of the Hispanic tradition. While these essays were more historical and religious, rather than architectural, in intent, they still provided information about the architecture of the time.

The next survey was published in 1964. Dominador Castañeda, former dean of the College of Fine Arts of the University of the Philippines (UP), published Art in the Philippines, a history of Philippine architecture, sculpture, and painting, which traces the development of these arts over the two colonial periods, and the modern period, until the 1960s. Castañeda interviewed a number of the architects mentioned in the book and conducted his research in the Philippine National Archives. Written in a narrative and descriptive fashion, the book aims to present a broad picture of Philippine architecture.

Another general survey of Philippine architecture is Winand Klassen’s Architecture in the Philippines: Filipino Building in a Cross-Cultural Context, 1968. The book posits that architecture mirrors a particular group’s quality of life. Klassen adopts the term vernacular architecture, rather than folk and indigenous architecture, for structures built by groups based on traditional wisdom.

Video documentaries and monographs on the Philippine arts were prepared by the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) under the general title of Tuklas Sining (Discover Art). Introductory in intent, some of the titles in the 28-title series include “Arkitektura, An Essay on Philippine Architecture,” 1989, by Rodrigo D. Perez III; “Philippine Ethnic Architecture,” 1992, by Corazon A. Hila; “The Spanish Influence on Philippine Architecture,” 1992, by Regalado Trota Jose; and “The American Colonial and Contemporary Traditions in Philippine Architecture,” 1994, also by Perez III.

The CCP then published the 10-volume CCP Encyclopedia of Philippine Art in 1994, revised and published as a CD-ROM in 1997. Volume 3 was dedicated to architecture. Arranged thematically, the encyclopedia begins with historical and contextual overview essays, including the four previously published separate monographs. Essays on architectural forms, outstanding examples of these forms, and the architects who built many of the important structures complete the encyclopedia. The CCP Encyclopedia set a benchmark on collective knowledge about architecture in the late 20th century.

After Castañeda, Klassen, and the CCP Encyclopedia, the next comprehensive survey of architecture is by Gerard Lico in 2008, titled Arkitekturang Filipino: A History of Architecture and Urbanism in the Philippines. It is written as a comprehensive textbook for architecture students and is currently used as a general introduction to architecture in the Philippines.

 

Indigenous Tradition and Transformation

Study of the indigenous traditions of architecture has been relatively recent, spurred by the nationalist ethos of the 1970s and the move toward Filipinization in the universities. Before the 1970s, studies about indigenous architecture were written in the context of ethnography and anthropology. The return to the Philippine folk and ethnic tradition in architecture was stimulated by the abundance of data on dwellings contained in numerous ethnographic studies in which architecture was studied in the context of a people’s life ways.

The earliest ethnographers, although they did not call themselves so, were the conquistadors and missionaries of the Spanish colonial period, whose duties included sending periodic reports to their superiors. The earliest reports of indigenous dwellings come from Ferdinand Magellan’s chronicler, Antonio Pigafetta, who in 1521, described at great length the houses he saw in Butuan. Later chroniclers, such as Pedro Chirino, Ignacio Alzina, Pedro Aduarte, and Juan de la Concepción, gave helpful descriptions of indigenous houses, although from a Western viewpoint. The 19th-century Cartas Edificantes of the Jesuit missionaries in Mindanao contain information on the dwellings of the Tiruray, Mandaya, and other indigenous peoples. American interest in ethnographic data arose from curiosity about their new possessions in the tropics. Among the important studies in the early 20th century were written by: Albert E. Jenks, The Bontoc Igorot, 1904; Fay-Cooper Cole, The Wild Tribes of Davao District, Mindanao, 1913; and John M. Garvan, The Manobos of Mindanao, 1931.

In 1929, Fr Francis M. Lambrecht, a Belgian missionary in the Cordilleras, published Ifugao Villages and Houses, a work which is significant for its thoroughness. William Henry Scott’s Cordillera Architecture in Northern Luzon was published in 1962, and proposed classifications of Cordillera houses into what he called the northern and southern strains. Studies on the different groups in the Cordillera include: Morice Vanoverbergh, “Isneg Buildings,” 1953; Moises C. Bello, “Some Notes on House Styles in a Kankanai Village,” 1963; Edward P. Dozier, The Kalinga of Northern Luzon, 1967; Carmencita Cawed, The Culture of the Bontoc Igorots, 1972; and Kate Botengan, Bontoc Lifeways, 1976.

Spanish scholarship on the indigenous tradition is found in the section on architecture in Arte Indigena del Norte de Filipinas, Los Grupos Etnicos de la Cordillera de Luzon (Indigenous Art of the Northern Philippines, the Ethnic Groups of the Cordillera of Luzon), published in 2012, which updates William Henry Scott’s 1962 article. The appendix contains transcriptions of some of the earliest Spanish accounts on the peoples of the Cordillera from 1576 to 1624, drawn from the Archivo General de Indias in Seville.

Other ethnographic studies on Luzon groups, which usually contained descriptions of dwelling and settlement patterns are: Lawrence L. Wilson, Ilongot Life and Legends, 1967; Ponciano L. Bennagen, “The Agta,” 1969; Marcelino N. Maceda, “A Brief Report on Some Mangyans in Northern Oriental Mindoro,” 1964; and Florentino H. Hornedo, “The Traditional Ivatan House,” 1983.

Studies on the Mindanao groups include: Jesus T. Peralta, “The Maranao,” 1969; Turan Ikiali Jainal, G. Rixhon, and D. Rupert, “Housebuilding among the Tausug”, 1972; Harry Arlo Nimmo, The Sea People of Sulu: A Study of Social Change in the Philippines, 1972; Nagasura Madale, “A Look at Philippine Mosques,” Salam, 1976; Cesar Adib Majul, “ Mosques in the Philippines,” 1977; and Gabriel S. Casal, Tboli Art in Its Socio-Cultural Context, 1978.

Studies on prehispanic settlements and dwellings based on archaeology include Robert B. Fox’s “Looking at the Prehispanic Community,” 1977, and Karl Hutterer’s An Archaeological Picture of a Pre-Spanish Cebuano Community, 1973.

Surveys of folk and indigeous architecture include: Julian Dacanay Jr, Ethnic Houses and Philippine Artistic Expression,1988; Felipe M. de Leon Jr, “The Architecture of the Philippines: A Survey” from Philippine Art and Literature, The Filipino Nation, Vol III, 1982; and Folk Architecture by Rodrigo D. Perez III, Rosario S. Encarnacion, and Julian E. Dacanay Jr, published in 1989, then probably the most comprehensive and best illustrated scholarly survey of Philippine indigenous houses from the Cordilleras to the Visayas to Sulu and Mindanao.

Interest in folk and indigenous architecture was promoted by the CCP’s traveling exhibit titled “Balai Vernacular.” Based on documentations made by architecture students from all over the islands, the exhibit documented three types of shelters: the indigenous house, the bahay kubo, and the shanty. Corazon Hila, Julian Dacanay Jr, and Rodrigo Perez III synthesized the findings of the exhibit in the book Balai Vernacular: Images of the Filipino’s Private Space, 1992.

In 1999, Abraham Sakili wrote a thesis submitted to UP titled “The Concept of Space and the Islamic Spatial Expression in the Traditional Architecture and Visual Arts of The Philippines,” which was the basis for his book, Space and Identity: Expressions in the Culture, Arts and Society of the Muslims in the Philippines published by the UP Asian Center in 2003.

 

Hispanic Tradition and Transformation

The Spanish colonial era has by far received the most scholarly attention, judging from the number of books and articles about this period when the traditions of East and West met in the Philippines. Studies have been made, not just by Philippine scholars, but also by those based in Spain and Mexico. These works may be divided into general surveys and those that focus on a topic with some depth.

General Works. A remarkable project was that of the Spanish scholar María Lourdes Díaz-Trechuelo Spínola, who combed the Spanish archives for material for her doctoral dissertation on Hispanic architecture in the Philippines. Published in 1959, Arquitectura Española en Filipinas(1565–1800) surpassed in scope all the research done in the Philippines up to that time. Diaz-Trechuelo’s work encompassed church, civil, and military architecture, and is notable for its study of fortifications. While enjoying access to a vast amount of important documents, the author did not have the benefit of fieldwork in the Philippines. Her careful historiography, made possible by the Spanish colonial bureaucracy’s obsessive thoroughness in documenting its work, succeeded in creating a picture of the many buildings demolished by war and calamities.

Another scholar, Pedro Ortiz Armengol, was an ambassador to the Philippines who took great interest in Intramuros, combining archival research and fieldwork. Intramuros de Manila, published in 1958, was generously illustrated with photographs and line drawings of buildings, and was based on an 18th century map of Intramuros. However, after these scholarly works, more than a decade was to pass before Spanish scholars would “rediscover” Philippine architecture.

Following these pioneers are early exploratory surveys. In 1968, Emilio Gomez Piñol embarked on a photographic journey all over the islands. The number of pictures of colonial buildings taken was comparable to that of the American Richard Ahlborn, who roamed the countryside some 10 years earlier. Gomez Piñol’s boxes of photographs were kept in the Universidad de Sevilla, but since his retirement their location is unknown. Gomez Piñol also produced a pioneering study, comparing Indo-Portuguese art with Hispano-Filipino art entitled Aspectos Generales de la Relacion Entre el Arte Indo-portugues y el Hispano-Filipino (General Aspects of the Relationship Between Indo-Portuguese and Hispano-Filipino Art), published in 1973.

According to Gomez Piñol, Indo-Portuguese architecture was characterized by strong Renaissance and Mannerist lines brought by Portuguese architects, but bearing Hindu, African, and even Mongol influences. The Golden Age of this art extends from 1510—the conquest of Goa, India by the Portuguese—to 1759, with the abandonment of Goa for better conditions in Panjim. Hispano-Filipino architecture, by comparison, may be said to have developed its own identity by mid-18th century when Hispanization had begun to take root. Gomez Piñol argues for the originality of Hispano-Filipino art, which incorporated influences from the indigenous, Spanish, Chinese, and Mexican cultures. He points out the tendency of facades to be composed of proportions of squares, an aspect explored more fully by Santiago Porras in 1991.

 

Arte en America y Filipinas (Art in America and the Philippines) published in 1973 by the eminent art historian Enrique Marco Dorta formed a volume of the encyclopedia Ars Hispaniae (Art of Spain). The short chapter on Philippine art included general comments on Intramuros, the Augustinian churches of Iloilo and Ilocos, the houses of Bustos, Bulacan, and the 19th century revival styles. Marco Dorta’s opinions were informed by notes from his student Emilio Gomez Piñol, who in 1974 in turn inherited his mentor’s post as Catedratico de Historia del Arte Hispanoamericano of the Universidad de Sevilla.

Another book, which describes Manila’s important public buildings, specifically the Aduana and the Puente de España, is Arquitectura y Urbanismo en el Siglo XIX (Architecture and Urbanism in the 19th Century) by Fr Luis Merino, OSA, published in 1967. The book reproduced important documents relating to the planning, building, renovation, and maintenance of these structures.

 

Pal Kelemen, a Hungarian historian of baroque and rococo art, wrote on the Philippines without ever leaving his adopted country, Mexico. In Art of the Americas: Ancient and Hispanic, with a Comparative Chapter on the Philippines, published in 1969, Kelemen observed that a thorough and careful study of Hispanic architecture in the Philippines was needed and would yield unexpected results. It was Kelemen who coined the phrase “earthquake baroque” to describe squat churches, particularly those in Peru. The term was adopted with great care by scholars, but was used with great abandon by the populace. Scholarly appreciation of the particular adaptation of baroque was evident in the works of this period.

Fr Luis Merino, an Augustinian based in San Agustin, Intramuros, produced two volumes of pioneering studies that touched on aspects of architecture during Spanish-period Manila: Estudios sobre el Municipio de Manila (Studies on the Municipality of Manila), published in 1983 and 1987. He posited that the chief of the building of Intramuros’s stone walls, Pedro Jusepe, was a Filipino. Other detailed essays dealt with the Ayuntamiento, the Aduana, the Puente de España, construction expenses, the Corps of Military Engineers, and the Earthquake Ordinances of 1880. A further two volumes, with articles on the Botanical Gardens, the electrification of Manila, the Carriedo fountain, firefighting, the urbanization of barrio San Nicolas, and the penitentiary system, unfortunately did not see the light. The Intramuros Administration posthumously named its library after Fr Merino.

 

Three decades after Maria Lourdes Diaz-Trechuelo Spinola’s 1959 dissertation Arquitectura Española en Filipinas, Santiago Porras Alvarez finished his doctoral dissertation, Asian Baroque: A Study on the Interaction Between the Iberian Baroque and the Native Cultures in South East Asia, in 1991. In two ways it characterized the broadening character of Spanish academia. It was written in English, and it was produced in the University of Tokyo.

From a database that included files for 104 structures and 75 measured drawings of colonial structures, mostly churches, in the Philippines, Porras was able to draw up a few hypotheses. Church plans and facades were drawn from modules of onebrazaby onebraza, or about six feet squared. A study of the manual prepared by Fr Juan Albarran for the Santo Niño church in Cebu reveals that many churches were built along the proportions propounded in the manual. Each region had its manner of varying these proportions. A summary of Porras’s findings, presented in a conference in Valladolid in 1996, was published in 1999.

In the Philippines, Doreen G. Fernandez and Jose M. Cruz’s The World of 1896, published 1998, has an essay on the status of architecture at the turn of the 19th century. In 1998, Nicanor G. Tiongson edited Igkas Arte: The Philippine Arts during the Spanish Period, which included an analytical and historical survey of architecture of the Spanish era by Rodrigo D. Perez III.

In 2002, an international conference was held in Manila under the auspices of Instituto Cervantes. International speakers were asked to address the theme of Fil-Hispanic architecture in the Philippines. The papers read at the conference were edited by Javier Galvan, who also participated in the conference. The proceedings were published as Endangered: Fil-Hispanic Architecture in 2005. Both the conference and the papers read discussed the appropriateness of using Hispanic rather than Spanish architecture to describe Philippine architecture from the late 16th to the 19th century. Characteristics of Filipinized Hispanic architecture were also discussed.

 

Some 13 years after Porras’s dissertation, Javier Galvan Guijo completed his Arquitectura y Urbanismo de Origen Español en el Pacifico Occidental (Architecture and Urbanism of Spanish Origin in the Western Pacific) in 2004. This doctoral dissertation earned Galvan the degree of Doctor Arquitecto from the Escuela Tecnica Superior de Arquitectura of the Universidad Politecnica de Madrid. The three volumes are the maturation of his earlier works, complemented by his being Director of the Instituto Cervantes in Manila from 2001 to 2006. The modern Fil-Hispanic building of the Instituto along T.M. Kalaw Street in Manila was designed by Galvan.

The first volume is a summation of Galvan’s observations and analyses of Philippine architecture during the Spanish period. Published versions of these, titled collectively as Manila, Occidente en Oriente (Manila, West in the East), appeared in 1998, 1999, 2002, 2003, and 2004. The second volume of Galvan’s dissertation, developed from a study published in 2001, is an in-depth analysis of the churches in the Cagayan Valley while the third volume deals with Hispanic architecture in Guam and other former Spanish possessions in the Pacific.

Galvan notes the irony that although Spanish researchers wrote about Philippine architecture through archival documents but without seeing the structures firsthand, the opposite was true for Filipino scholars. Thus Galvan illustrates his discussion on “Arquitectura Filhispana” with examples and images from his extensive trips throughout the Philippines. In fact, he proposes that the church complexes built during the Spanish era, with all their influences and techniques, are the most emblematic of Philippine architectural patrimony.

He finds that what is “miraculous” in San Agustin church is not necessarily its survival to this day, but its plan. The stone church begun in 1591 is a rectangle enclosing a cruciform flanked by side altars, quite similar to the revolutionary one of Vignola for Il Gesú in Rome, consecrated only seven years before in 1584. A significant chapter deals with gems of architecture in Intramuros and its environs that have since disappeared. A section on the possible sources of the octagonal form in Fil-hispanic architecture (Spanish, Mexican, Islamic, Chinese) was developed from a talk that Galvan presented in a conference in 2002.

Forms and Types. The international academic portrayal of Philippine colonial architecture as a land of churches and forts was expanded by a number of contributions on other forms, like hospitals, bahay na bato (stone house), lighthouses, and bridges.

Churches and Conventos. Before World War II, studies on churches had already been published. In 1937, Raymundo C. Bañas published Brief Historical Sketches of Philippine Catholic Churches, in time for the celebration of the 33rd International Eucharistic Congress held in Manila that year. This book is the earliest survey of colonial churches. It presents data, which are more historical than architectural, on famous churches, such as the churches of pre-World War II Intramuros and the churches of Santa Ana, Ermita, Binondo, Santa Cruz, Sampaloc, San Sebastian, Pandacan, Malate, Paco, Quiapo, and San Miguel in the Manila area, as well as Obando, Maasin, and Cebu outside Manila.

 

William C. Repetti’s Pictorial Records and Traces of the Society of Jesus in the Philippine Islands and Guam Prior to 1768 was published in 1938 by the archivist of the Jesuit mission in the Philippines. The book was the result of attempts to add to the data of the archives. The author was assisted by Brother Dunne and Father Gissel, who took most of the photographs. In response to his letters, parish priests in the towns formerly under the Jesuit order sent him information as well as photographs of the churches. Repetti, however, was merely content with cataloguing and notating the pictures he compiled. Some notes are inaccurate, as subsequent research proved.

After World War II, more architectural publications were produced. A similar survey of churches was done by Fr Jose Ma. Gonzalez in his Labor Evangelica y Civilizadora de los Religiosos Dominicos en Pangasinan (Evangelical and Civilizing Work of the Dominican Religious in Pangasinan). Published in 1946, it gave historical data on the parishes, churches, conventos, and public buildings of Pangasinan, and describes them in the context of the evangelization of the province. Visitacion de la Torre published Faith Enshrined: Churches of Pangasinan.

However, the war also reduced the numerous architectural monuments of the Spanish and American periods. With such widespread destruction, there was very little architectural history written for many years. Instead, collectors and avid nationalists sought to salvage what was left of the past. From these practices, there developed a reassessment of the colonial heritage. During the first half of the century, Philippine architecture was evaluated from the viewpoint of the West. Measured by Western standards, such as John Ruskin’s, Philippine architecture seemed nothing more than a poor offshoot of European architecture. Soon the writers of the 1950s began to take local architecture on its own terms. Not unfamiliar with Western architecture, they had the advantage of being Filipinos or of spending much of their lives in the Philippines.

The first structures to be reevaluated were the colonial churches. Questioning the assumption that colonial churches were derivative in form and ornament, Benito Legarda, Fernando Zobel de Ayala, and others sought to document what was left of these structures after the devastation of war. The result of their excursions to the provinces in the late 1950s was the publication of Legarda’s “Colonial Churches of Ilocos” in Philippine Studies, and by Zobel on the santo, an integral element of colonial architecture. Zobel’s article was to be expanded into a book, Philippine Religious Imagery, published in 1963, which contained a section on the Philippine bahay na bato (stone house) and drew parallels between architectural and sculptural styles. Legarda continued his research on northern Luzon churches and in 1981 published “Angels in Clay: The Typical Cagayan Church Style” in the Filipinas Journal 2. Legarda also posed the question whether there might be regional styles, and set out to prove this in a study of the Cagayan churches. Zobel’s study on the santo proposed stylistic categories, such as popular, classical, and ornate.

Richard Ahlborn, an American, published two articles in Philippine Studies from 1960 to 1963 on the churches of central Luzon, notably those of Rizal and Bulacan. An overview and interpretative study appeared two years earlier, in the Exchange News Quarterly in 1958. Ahlborn returned to the US and worked with the Smithsonian Institute in Washington, DC, where his collection of photographs of churches was kept in his office. Since his death, the collection has been bequeathed to Tulane University’s Latin American Library in Howard-Tilton Memorial University.

In 1972, Alicia Marquez Lim-Coseteng published Spanish Churches in the Philippines under the auspices of UNESCO and its National Commission in the Philippines. While viewing colonial churches in the context of the strategies of evangelization and colonial control, Lim-Coseteng analyzed their architectural features and cites their artistic value. However, no major survey of colonial churches appeared until Fr Pedro Galende published his book on Augustinian churches, Angels in Stone, in 1987, which was republished in a new format with colored pictures in 2000. The author had access to many sources in the Augustinian archives and succeeded in documenting the historical setting, growth, and development of each church. The book is limited to churches held solely by Augustinians. Churches that were transferred to the jurisdiction of another group, like the Franciscans, are excluded.

Another researcher, Florentino Hornedo, specialized in the churches of the Cagayan Valley and the Batanes Islands. He has published articles on the evangelizing work of the Dominicans and on the churches and their friar builders. His works have appeared in popular magazines and in the scholarly journals of the University of Santo Tomas. His essays include “Religious Art in Batanes” in 1983 and “The Tumauini Church: Praise of 100">Sublime Labor in Clay” in 1987.

In 1991, Norma I. Alarcon published Philippine Architecture during the Pre-Spanish and Spanish Period, a broad textbook survey of architecture in the Philippines, both public and private, in the indigenous and Hispanic traditions. The biggest section of the book is devoted to Spanish period churches, whose history and characteristic architectural features are listed.

More works on colonial churches are Regalado Trota Jose’s Simbahan and René B. Javellana’s Wood and Stone for God’s Greater Glory, both published in 1991. The former is a catalogue and survey of colonial churches from Batanes to Jolo. Intended as an aid for the documentation of churches, the text describes a colonial church in great detail. Trota Jose has done fieldwork all over the islands and used archival documents from local repositories extensively. Javellana’s book is a historical summary and catalogue of the Jesuit order’s building enterprise over two periods: 1581 to 1768, and 1859 to World War II. The book uses material from both local and foreign archives and fieldwork to piece together the story of the Jesuits’ contribution to Philippine art and architecture.

In 2002, Hornedo published On the Trail of Dominican Engineers, Artists and Saints in the Cagayan Valley and Batanes which brought together his research on the Dominicans’s architectural activities. In 2003, Maria Teresa Padilla Quevedo submitted a thesis to UP entitled “The Theory and Framework of Mission Architecture of Ituy and Paniqui.” In 2008, Romero B. Galang Jr submitted a thesis to UP entitled “A Cultural History of the Santo Domingo Ecclesiastical Complex in Intramuros, Manila: 1587-1900.”

In 2010, Javellana’s La Casa de Dios: The Legacy of Filipino-Hispanic Architecture was published as a historical introduction to colonial churches, based on the photographic collection of the Ortigas Foundation. The book was the foundation for an exhibit on colonial churches titled “Los Vinculos Duraderos con España: Las Iglesias de Filipinas” (Lasting Links with Spain: the Churches of the Philippines), which opened at the Casa América located at the Palacio Linares in Madrid on 28 Nov 2014.

All of the studies listed above had the common purpose of discovering and identifying the distinctly Philippine features of colonial churches. For countless years they were called “Spanish churches,” but decades of research have shown that they had many non-Spanish elements that had not been previously recognized. Calling them Philippine churches is not only nationalistically sound but architecturally accurate. Philippine Churches, the popular coffee table book published by the National Media Production Center in 1980, makes this point clearly. But beginning in 2002, during the international conference on Fil-Hispanic architecture, scholars began favoring the term “Hispanic” rather than “Spanish” to describe these churches. Javellana argues in La Casa de Dios that the influences and sources of Philippine colonial architecture are more precisely termed Hispanic rather than Spanish because influences on architecture are also derived from Mexico and Peru.

Balaanong Bahandi: Sacred Treasures of Cebu by J. Eleazar Bersales, which was published by the Cathedral Museum of Cebu and San Carlos University Press in 2010, is about the colonial churches of Cebu. Historical data was culled from the 1886 Breve Reseña de lo que Fue y de lo que Es la Diocesis de Cebu (A Brief Review of the Past and Present of the Diocese of Cebu) by Father Felipe Redondo y Sendino, but updated by its authors. Intended to complement the book on Cebu was a work on Bohol churches, but the earthquake of Oct 2013 damaged so many structures that it was impossible to study them. The book was redesigned to show the effects of the earthquake by juxtaposing before and after photographs. Authored by Bersales, with photographs by Fr Generoso Rebalya, SVD and Estan Cabigas, the book was titled Pagsulay: Churches of Bohol Before and after the Earthquake of 2013, and published by San Carlos Press. Similarly, Regalado Trota Jose’s works on Fil-Hispanic churches, amply documented with photographs, was included in a series in Philippiniana Sacra, a journal published by the University of Santo Tomas.

To date, Pedro Luengo Gutierrez is the most productive researcher in the field of Spanish scholarship; not only on Fil-Hispanic architecture but on Fil-Hispanic arts in general. This capacity for research must be credited to the tradition of scholarship at the Department of Art History in the Universidad de Sevilla. Luengo’s first work on Fil-Hispanic architecture is Arquitectura Conventual en Manila 1571-1645 (Conventual Architecture in Manila 1571-1645), which earned him a Diploma in Advanced Studies in 2008 from the Universidad de Sevilla. It deals with the churches and institutions of the religious orders in Intramuros from the founding of Manila in 1571 until the disastrous earthquake of 1645.

Arquitectura Conventual was followed by Luengo’s doctoral dissertation Intramuros: Arquitectura en Manila 1739-1762 in 2010, which was published in 2012. Tracing the building of such emblematic structures as the Franciscan Church and Convent, the Cathedral, and the Alcaiceria de San Fernando led Luengo to single out the decade from 1750 to 1760 as one of the most brilliant in the history of Philippine architecture. The data that Luengo obtained was enough to produce another book, which became Manila, Plaza Fuerte (1762-1788), published in 2013. This third volume expands the contributions of military engineers beyond fortifications to include churches and civil structures.

Fortifications. A version of Fernando Valdes Tamon’s 1738relaciontranslated as Report in Which, By Order of His Catholic Majesty … the Strongholds, Castles, Forts and Garrisons of the Provinces Under His Royal Protection in the Philippine Islands Are Listed was published in 1995. It was a transcription and translation of a report submitted to the Spanish king about the status of Philippine fortifications. It contains reproductions of the plans that accompanied the report.

Javellana’s Fortress of Empire: Spanish Colonial Fortifications of the Philippines, 1565-1898 in 1997, is the first published study on colonial fortifications in the Philippines. This was complemented by an unpublished eight-volume documentation on fortifications made for the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) in 2008. Part of the data in that report has been published online, in a website called Muog.

Hospitals. Spanish scholar Juan Antonio Casero Nieto specialized in the history of hospitals in the Philippines. His licensure thesis was on hospitals founded by the Franciscans, called “Hospitales Fundados por los Franciscanos Españoles en Filipinas, entre 1578-1898” (Hospitals Founded by the Spanish Franciscans in the Philippines between 1578 and 1898), while his doctoral dissertation was on the organization of hospitals during the Spanish period, titled “La Organizacion Hospitalaria en Filipinas Durante la Colonizacion Española” (The Hospital Organizations in the Philippines During the Spanish Colonization). The data in these works were integrated in a hefty study on hospitals in Spanish America and the Philippines by Francisco Guerra, titled El Hospital en Hispanoamerica y Filipinas 1492-1898 (The Hospital in Spanish America and the Philippines, 1492-1898), published in 1994. A total of 96 Philippine institutions was listed and described, ranging from hospitals to infirmaries and from leprosaria to hospices. Guerra was not only a medical doctor, but also held doctorate degrees in science, history and philosophy. Finally, Fr Cayetano Sanchez Fuertes, a Franciscan archivist in Madrid, wrote “Hospitales y Enfermerias de los Franciscanos en Extremo Oriente” (Franciscan hospitals and infirmaries in the Far East) and “El hospital Franciscano de los Naturales de Filipinas, siglos xvi-xvii” (The Franciscan Hospital of the Natives of the Philippines, 16th and 17th centuries), rounding out the research done on hospital architecture.

Infrastructure. Other scholars turned their attention to engineering and public works. In 1992, Ignacio Gonzalez Tascon’s hefty two-volume work, Ingenieria Española en Ultramar: Siglos XVI-XIX (Spanish Engineering Overseas, 16th-19th centuries), was published in Madrid by the College of Engineers of Roads, Canals, and Ports. The section on the Philippines deals with the building of bridges, dams, and waterways, with emphasis on the Puente de España and the Carriedo waterworks. It is well illustrated with archival drawings, plans, and photographs.

Launched in 1992, Miguel Angel Sanchez Terry’s Faros Españoles de Ultramar (Spanish Lighthouses Overseas) was published by Spain’s Ministry of Public Works and Transport. For the Philippines, 40 large and small lighthouses are described, along with 14 others that were planned but not completed. Each of the 54 structures—from Aparri to Jolo—is presented with a building history, technical specifications, location map, plans, and photographs. The maps and plans and most of the photographs are taken from archival sources. The author’s great-grandfather was a port captain in Manila in the late 19th century.

Other notable works include Manuel Noche’s Lonely Sentinels of the Sea: the Spanish Lighthouses in the Philippines, published in 2005. It is about 19th century lighthouses and contains archival and recent photographs of these lighthouses. His second book Puentes de España en las Filipinas: The Spanish Colonial Bridges of the Philippines, focuses on the much forgotten legacy of the Spanish era.

Naval Engineering. Jesus Garcia del Valle Gomez’s Retrato de un Navio. Nuestra Señora del Pilar de Zaragoza de la Carrera Manila-Acapulco (1733-1750) (Portrait of a Ship: Our Lady of the Pillar of Zaragoza, of the Manila-Acapulco Route, 1733-1750), published in 1993, is an excellent source for Philippine naval architecture, using the ship baptizedNuestra Señora del Pilar de Zaragozaas its primary example. Built in the Cavite shipyards, thePilardisappeared in 1750 while traversing the Pacific Ocean on its fifth voyage to Acapulco. The author, an engineer and naval historian, distinguishes among certain types of ocean-going vessels all known as galleons. Thegaleonwas prevalent in the 17th century but the last of its type built in the Philippines was in 1718. It was supplanted by the more complex ship called thenavio. A smaller version of the navio used often as a patrol ship was thepatache; this latter ship and its cousin thefragata(frigate) replaced the navio in the latter years of the Manila-Acapulco Trade.

Sanchez Terry, Noche, and Valle Gomez’s works point to the key role that the Manila-Acapulco trade played in the development of the Philippines. In particular, the cultural trade that occurred during the Manila-Acapulco trade was of interest to Ana Ruiz Gutierrez, a professor of art history at the Universidad de Granada. A specialist on Fil-Hispanic art, her El Trafico Artistico entre España y Filipinas (1565-1815) (The Artistic Exchange Between Spain and the Philippines, 1565-1815), published 2005, deals with the exchange of artistic goods between Spain and the Philippines during the Galleon Trade, which lasted from 1565 to 1815.

In line with this transnational exchange are the works of Mexican scholars. A doctor and architect teaching at the Universidad de Colima, Adolfo Gomez Amador has pointed to the palapa, the native hut on the western coast of Mexico, as a structure influenced by Filipino architecture. Filipinos who arrived on Mexican soil brought with them the coconut palm, the process of making coconut wine ortuba, and the technique of using the coconut leaf, thepalapa, as roofing material. Gomez Amador’s findings, first published in 2000 and 2001, were refined in 2014 “Palapa: Una Tecnologia que Trajo el Galeon de Manila” (Palapa: a Technology Brought by the Manila Galleon). Additional confirmation for Gomez would be the town of Palapag in Northern Samar, an important Philippine port along the Manila-Acapulco route, and the Tagalog wordpalapag, which means a level in a house, or a temporary platform.

For Juan B. Artigas, the palapa, or palm roof in Mexico, is derived from the Tagalog palapala, or a shed of light materials. An architectural historian, Artigas points this out as one aspect linking the barely studied fields of Mexican and Philippine architecture. In his Arquitectura a Cielo Abierto en Iberoamerica Como un Invariante Continental (Open-Air Architecture in Iberoamerica as a Continental Invariable Characteristic), published 2008, Artigas cites the wide atriums in front of Philippine churches, regularly marked by Stations of the Cross or capillas posas (small outdoor oratories) as evidence of the shared Ibero-American heritage of open-air architecture.

In a short paper delivered in Manila in 2006 and published in 2010, the architect Jorge Loyzaga pointed out that the large atrio found in front of many churches was found only in Mexico and the Philippines. In his “La Arquitectura Filipina Durante el Virreinato Novohispano y las Influencias que Llegaron al Archipelago” (Philippine Architecture during the Viceroyalty of New Spain and the Influences that Reached the Archipelago), Loyzaga emphasized that the basic origin of Spanish colonial architecture in the Philippines was not from Spain, but from Mexico.

Bahay na Bato. The search for Philippine architecture led to a serious study of the bahay na bato. Unsurpassed in scope and depth is Fernando Zialcita and Martin Tinio Jr’s Philippine Ancestral Houses, published in 1980, which documents the evolution of the bahay na bato from the 1810s to the 1930s. The bahay na bato is dissected from a structural point of view and is shown to have incorporated design concepts from the bahay kubo, the traditional nipa hut.

Raquel Baltazar-Florendo’s “Las Casas Bajo de la Campanas: A Socio-cultural Approach to the Study of Interior Spaces of Principalia Dwellings in Vigan Ilocos Sur, 1800-1900” was published as Las Casas Bajo de la Campanas in 2012. An important study of a particular bahay na bato in Cebu’s Parian, which situates and explains important structures in its sociohistorical context, is Casa Gorordo in Cebu, Urban Residence in a Philippine Province by Resil B. Mojares. Commissioned by the Ramon Aboitiz Foundation, Inc in 1983, the study relates the Gorordo residence to the urbanization of Cebu in the 19th century. In other parts of the Visayas, Casa Boholana: Vintage Houses of Bohol by Erik Akpedonu and Czarina Saloma, published in 2013 by the Ateneo de Manila University Press, records the many bahay na bato from the 19th century that have been preserved in Bohol.

Major Works. In addition to the general works and the works on specific genres of Hispanic structures in the Philippines, there have been studies on specific buildings or sites in this tradition. Arts professor Marilyn Canta completed her masters thesis at the UP in 1990, “An Architectural History of the Churches of Camarines Sur, 1578-1898,” an area evangelized by the Franciscans, beginning with its pioneers Frs Juan de Plasencia and Diego de Oropesa, OFM. That same year, another thesis in UP that focused on specific architectural histories were Honey Libertine R. Achanzar’s “The Philippine Kampana: Its Sonic and Non-Sonic Meaning.”

In 1995, Marie Joy Buendia Rosal submitted “An Art Historical Study of Spanish Period Stone Cemeteries in Iloilo.” Marta Manchado Lopez wrote “El Proyecto de Convento Para Mestizas de Santa Rosa de Lima, en Filipinas” (The Proposed Convent for Mestizas of Santa Rosa de Lima in the Philippines) in 1999, regarding the unsuccessful project to build a convento for the daughters of Filipina mothers and Chinese fathers in Binondo, Manila.

In 1993, Frs Jose Maria Martinez and Nicolas Salvatierra, OAR wrote, “The Basilica of San Sebastian.” In 1994, Evelyn Vergara submitted to UP a thesis entitled “The Manila Cathedral, 1571-1896: An Architectural History.” Rupert Santos, former archivist of the Archdiocese of Manila, published a monograph, Manila Cathedral, Minor Basilica of the Immaculate Conception, 1997, illustrated with plans and photographs from the Roman Catholic Archives of Manila. Alfredo J. Morales’s “Una Catedral para Manila” (A Cathedral for Manila), 2003, described the process of building the Manila Cathedral in the 17th and 18th centuries.

Regalado Trota Jose’s Visita Iglesia Bohol: A Guide to Historic Churches was published by the NCCA. Similarly, the Ramon Aboitiz Foundation, Inc. has published a guide to the heritage sites of Argao, Cebu, many of which are from the Spanish colonial era, like the church complex, the enclosed patio with its capillas posas, the municipal hall, remnants of defensive wall and its gate, a mortuary, and several bahay na bato, the oldest of which is behind the church.

In 1999, Lorelei D. Del Castillo submitted to UP “A History of Architecture in Binondo, 1594-1898: A Socio-cultural Study of the Architecture of Binondo.” This became the basis for a history of architecture in Binondo which was published in 2001 by the UST Press as Three Centuries of Binondo Architecture 1594-1898: A Socio-historical Perspective.

Paul Gershwiler’s Bolhoon: A Cultural Sketch, 2009, is about the town of Bolhoon in Cebu. The heart of this town is the Church of Nuestra Señora del Patrocinio. Bolhoon is an example of town history that adds to an understanding and appreciation of the Hispanic tradition.

René B. Javellana’s In & Around Intramuros: An Interactive Guide in 2003 offers five schemes for a walking tour of the walled city of Intramuros. Each tour allows for a sampling of the urban and architectural features of this historic city. Ramon Ma. Zaragoza’s Villa Fernandina, Ilocos Sur, published in 2004, is a pictorial history of Vigan.

Bruce Leonard Fenner’s Cebu Under the Spanish Flag, 1521-1896: An Economic and Social History, was first published in 1985, and reprinted in 2004 by the University of San Carlos. While not directly about architecture, it gives the context for the rise and decline of Cebu, especially the Parian, which was the residence of the entrepreneurial Cebuano mestizos who left behind many heritage bahay na bato like Casa Gorordo and the Yap-San Diego House.

An uncommon topic on the Spanish era is Cheek Sangalang Fadriquela’s 2013 book Kahoy: Wood in the Philippines, Wood and its Uses from the Pre-Hispanic to Spanish Colonial Philippines. Because wood was an important building material, Fadriquela’s two-volume work is able to relate wood to diverse topics like the 1887 Philippine Exposition in Parque del Retiro in Madrid, the Pagrel Collection at the San Agustin Museum, the restoration of the Pasig Cathedral, the collection of heritage houses of Las Casas de Acuzar in Balanga, Bataan, the adaptive reuse of a Spanish colonial jail, the Carcel de Cebu, as the Museo Sugbo, and a study of wood carving centers in the Philippines in the Cordilleras, Pampanga, Laguna, Bohol, Lanao del Sur, Sulu, and Manila.

Exhibitions on the Spanish Colonial Era. In 1998, celebrating the Centennial of Philippine Independence, Spain sponsored Manila 1571-1898 Occidente en Oriente, with an accompanying catalogue, at the San Agustin Museum. The project aimed to show the implantation of Western culture in the East, chiefly through architectural heritage. It was conceptualized by the Universidad de Alcala’s Instituto Español de Arquitectura, the Spanish Ministry of Foreign Affairs’ Spanish Agency for International Cooperation (AECI), the Spanish Ministry of Industry, the Center for Studies and Experimentation on Public Works (CEDEX), and the Center for Historical Studies on Public Works and Urbanism (CEHOPU). The exhibition was curated by the architect Javier Aguilera Rojas, who also wrote the general texts of the catalogue. Artifacts were borrowed from at least 18 institutions in Spain, two in Mexico, and one in the United Kingdom. A three-dimensional model of the famous 1720s map of Manila by Antonio Fernandez de Rojas, and intricate miniature replicas of the Alcaiceria de San Fernando, the Puente de Ayala, the Puente de España, the Ayuntamiento, and the Manila Cathedral were also commissioned.

Most of the articles in the catalogue are of architectural interest. The richly illustrated catalogue boasted articles by some of the best Spanish experts of Philippine history, including Pedro Ortiz Armengol and Maria Lourdes Diaz Trechuelo Spinola. There were also articles by Filipino scholars Augusto Villalon and Fernando Zialcita.

Isabel Ma. Garcia Garcia’s Bibliografia sobre Obras Publicas, Urbanismo y Arquitectura en Filipinas (Bibliography on Public Works, Urbanism, and Architecture) is a painstakingly compiled bibliography culled from Spanish and Philippine sources. The earliest item is Valdes Tamon’s 1739 “Relacion” but the list jumps to 1850 and continues to contemporary works. Particularly noteworthy are articles prepared by Spanish architects and engineers during the last half-century of colonial rule, such as Antonio Domenech, Carlos de la Heras, Eduardo Lopez Navarro, Alejandro Olano, and Genaro Palacios.

Ma. Soledad Hernandez Paez de la Cadena’s La Planimetria de Filipinas en los Archivos Españoles (The Planometry of the Philippines in Spanish Archives) traces the archiving in Spain of more than 8,000 maps and plans on the Philippines. Of these, around 3,000 contain architectural, engineering, or urbanistic information. They are housed primarily in various archives in Spain. Many of these works are of artistic value. The list of names of engineers who signed the plans numbers more than 200.

Dolores Romero Muñoz’s “Puertos, Rios, Canales: La Ingenieria Española en Manila” (Ports, Rivers, Canals: Spanish Engineering in Manila) and Amaya Saenz Sanz’s “Los Ingenieros de Caminos y las Comunicaciones en Filipinas en la Segunda Mitad del Siglo XIX: El ferrocarril” (The Engineers of Roads and Communication in the Philippines in the Second Half of the 19th Century: The Railroad) dealt with engineering projects. However, both articles emphasize the close relationship between engineers and architecture.

Reproduction of Graphic and Textual Material. Apart from academic discourses, another important contribution of Spanish scholarship is the reproduction of graphic and textual material from archives. Justa Moreno Garbayo’s Fiestas en Manila año 1825 in 1977 reproduces an album of watercolors documenting the decoration of buildings for the reception of the King’s portrait in Manila in 1825. Fiestas is an especially significant guide for the colors used for buildings at that time. In 1992, the Spanish Ministry of Public Works re-issued Rafael Cerero’s 1890 Estudio Sobre la Resistencia y Estabilidad de los Edificios Sometidos a Huracanes y Terremotos (A Study on the Resistance and Stability of Buildings Subjected to Hurricanes and Earthquakes) with an Introduction by Alfonso Lopez Arroyo. Cerero’s Estudio was based on actual field experience in the Philippines—the equations, recommendations, and strategies are still relevant more than a century after its publication. The plates present wooden joinery details and examples of useful hardware.

Aspects from the collection of architectural plans and drawings in the National Archives of the Philippines were presented in an exhibition at the Intramuros Administration in 1995. The curator of the exhibition was Belen Bañas, then a researcher sent by the Spanish Agency for Cultural Cooperation, to assist in the cataloguing of the National Archives. A catalogue of the exhibition, Imagenes de Filipinas (Siglos XVIII-XIX), was also published. A generous selection of architectural drawings and plans from the Spanish Ministry of Defense, the Servicio Historico Militar and Servicio Geografico del Ejercito, was also published in 1996. Volume 10 of Cartografia y Relaciones Historicas de Ultramar (Cartography and Historical Relations Overseas) is dedicated to the Philippines and comprises two books. Of special interest is the series of plans on military installations in Mindanao and Sulu.

 

American Colonial Tradition

Research on the architecture of the American colonial era is not as extensive as that on the Spanish colonial era. There is no single publication that focuses on the American era alone. This is a big gap in architectural research because the half-century of American rule was characterized by a massive, systematic, and intense architectural and infrastructure program, funded by the Insular government, to transform the Philippines into a bastion and paradigm of “American-style democracy” in Asia. The program involved building roads and bridges, improving and upgrading what the Spanish had left; modernizing the railroad and other means of transportation, and building government offices, schools, hospitals, and providing the citizenry with amenities like parks, and recreational areas. Governance, health and sanitation, and education were high in the American agenda. This was also the era when art nouveau and art deco were introduced to the Philippines, rivaling the revivalist styles already introduced in the 19th century.

 

The work of Lourdes Montinola as editor and writer of Art Deco in the Philippines, published by Artpost Asia, comes as a welcome addition to studies on the American period. Despite the meager publication on the American era, there has been scholarly work in the form of thesis and dissertations submitted to the UP, such as Veronica Amarra Dado’s 1996 study titled “Philippine public elementary school buildings during the American Period, 1898-1941,” which is about public schools in the Manila area. Gerardo Lucena’s 1998 thesis, “The Religious Paintings of San Beda Church, Abbey of Montserrat (The Allegories and the Apotheosis) Manila, 1930-1934,” was about the work of Dom Lesmes Lopez, a Spaniard, and Bro Salvador Alberich, who decorated the neo-Gothic church of the Abbey built between Feb 1925 and Jan 1926.

 

Josefina S. Pineda’s 2008 thesis “Sining sa Libingan: Sementerio de Dilao at Sementerio del Norte de Manila (1814-1941)” is about cemeteries. Although the starting year begins during the Spanish colonial era, its terminal year is 1941, the eve of World War II. Since sanitation and health were concerns of the American government, Pineda’s study fits in with the spirit of American era architecture.

The works and career of Isabelo Tampinco, a sculptor who provided sculpture and decorative pieces for churches, public buildings, and homes, spanned the Spanish and American era. He made his name in the 19th century with his work on the Santo Domingo and the San Ignacio churches, and later on the Legislative Building, the Central Post Office, the Metropolitan Theater, and the Legarda public school designed by Andres Luna de San Pedro in the early 20th century. He introduced tropical motifs in his version of art deco, called estilo Tampinco. The National Museum of the Philippines and Vibal Foundation published The Art and Life of Isabelo Tampinco by Santiago Albano Pilar on the occasion of the opening of the Tampinco Gallery at the National Museum of the Philippines’ Museum of Fine Arts, in 2014.

 

Visual references for the American era are found in a handful of books on vintage postcards and photographs. Although photography was introduced during the Spanish colonial era, its popularity and widespread use came during the American era. A couple of books that have been published show pictures of architecture from the end of the Spanish era but mostly from the American colonial era. In 1994, Jonathan Best published Philippine Picture Postcards 1900-1920 and in 1998, Philippine Album: American Era Photographs 1900-1930 under Bookmark, Inc. Lucy Urgello Miller, in 2010, published Glimpses of Old Cebu: Images of the Colonial Era, containing a selection of photographs and postcards from the thousands she has collected. Many of them showcased architectural buildings and styles. Published digitally is Gerard Lico’s The Philippines through the lens of an American soldier (1898-1907): The Harry Whitfield Harnish photographic collection in 2004, which contains images of American-era buildings.

 

The Period of the Republics

The contemporary period began in 1946, the year of Philippine Independence, and runs to the present. It may be divided into Republic III, 1946-1972; Republic IV, 1972-1986; Republic V, 1986 to the present. Because the sections will be too short for lack of published research, this essay will not make further subdivisions into the different eras of the Republic.

In addition to books, many of the research conducted during this time was also published electronically, such as the works from the NCCA which came out in CDs, which included the works of UP professor and writer Gerard Lico, Arkitekturang Filipino: Sources and Places in History in 2002, and Building Modernity: A Century of Philippine Architecture and the Allied Arts in 2008. While they are general works that straddle the various periods, they also bring the discussion of architecture to the present.

Two general works that discuss Philippine style in architecture were edited by Elizabeth Reyes, titled Filipino Style, 2004, and Philippine Style: Design and Architecture, 2013. Although both begin with the indigenous and the Hispanic tradition, the books focus on the transformation and contemporary use of these heritage styles, especially in domestic architecture. Thus, styles are read through the vantage of contemporary design practice.

Gerard Lico’s 2000 thesis, “Edifice Complex: The Discourse of Power in Marcos State Architecture at the Cultural Center of the Philippines” is an authoritative source on martial law architecture. This thesis was subsequently published by Ateneo de Manila University Press in 2003 as Edifice Complex: Power, Myth, and Marcos State Architecture.

Many publications on the contemporary period are about the specific architectural projects, sites or works or the career and life work of Philippine architects. Ma. Alessandra L. Hermano and Josephine L. Hermano’s 2001 book At Home with Filipino Art and Artists, features the homes and ateliers of 21 artists. The book is an unusual take on contemporary architecture as it shows Filipino artists’ homes and studios in the Philippines and abroad, some conventional, others quirky, set in various settings, urban or rural, on a mountain-top or by the sea, close to the ground or in a high rise.

Tahanan: A House Reborn, published in 2003 by Reynaldo G. Alejandro and Vicente Roman S. Santos, focuses on the heritage rescue of the residence of Roman R. Santos, built in Navotas in 1917. Threatened by destruction due to flooding, heavy traffic, and urban decay, the descendants of Santos transferred their ancestral home to Antipolo in 2002. The process was carefully documented and serves as guide to similar tasks of rescue.

Manuel Quezon III, Paulo Alcazaren, and Jeremy Barns came out with Malacañan Palace: The Official Illustrated History in 2005. This book traces the history of Malacañan and its transformation through renovation, remodeling, and expansion, especially in 1979 during the Marcos era, and the restoration done under Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo.

Other architectural books came out in the 2000s. In 2007, Turning Pages: 50 Years of Bel-Air, edited by Cid Reyes, was a commemorative coffee table book for one of Makati’s pioneer gated village. Heartbeat: Manila Hilton, published in 2011 and edited by Marla Yotoko Chorengel and Letty Jacinto Lopez, was a collection of short essays about the planning, construction, and grand opening of the Manila Hilton in 1968.

Paulo G. Alcazaren also edited Parks for a Nation: The Rizal Park and 50 Years of the National Parks Development Committee in 2013. It tells the history of the National Parks Development Committee and its signature and principal park in Manila. As an open space, Rizal Park was integral to the 1905 design of Daniel H. Burnham for the capital city, Manila. Over the years the park was transformed, modified, and built over. Illustrated with vintage and new photographs, the book shows the visual richness of the park and highlights the role it plays in the life of a city.

The Philippine Arena: A Monument to An Enduring Faith was published by Iglesia ni Cristo in 2014, on the occasion of its centennial. It documents, through text and photographs, the construction of a state-of-the-art sports arena and meeting place.

Many contemporary works also focus on architects and their legacies. Architecture of Leandro Locsin by Nicholas Polites from 1977 is about National Artist Locsin, who designed the UP Church of the Holy Sacrifice and the Isatana Nurul Iman Palace in Brunei, as well as office buildings, cultural centers, and theaters, like the demolished Rizal Theater in Makati.

Pioneer and Modernist Iconoclast: The Architectural Legacy of Pablo S. Antonio by Gerard Lico is about National Artist Pablo S. Antonio, who was posthumously awarded in 1976. After completing his architecture degree in the University of London, as a scholar of his firm Mapua, Arevalo, Siochi Construction Co, Antonio designed buildings that departed from the traditional classicist strain. Among others, he designed the FEU Complex and the Ramon Roces Publication Building.

Designing Filipino: The Architecture of Francisco Mañosa and Beyond the Bahay Kubo: 16 Climate Conscious Tropical Homes by the Mañosas by Eric Caruncho document the design philosophy of the Mañosas, who work with the enduring qualities of vernacular architecture, like lightness and being light-filled, dialogue between outdoor and indoor and the use of natural material.

Other collections on Philippine architects and their works have been published. Ludette Zaragosa-Banson and Ruben D. F. Defeo’s Jose V. Zaragoza: Architecture for God, for Man focuses on the churches and residences designed by Jose V. Zaragoza; The Landscape Architecture of Ildefonso P. Santos by Jeannie J. Javelosa is about Ildefonso Paez Santos’s pioneering work in landscape architecture, for which he was given numerous awards including the prestigious National Artist Award for landscape architecture. Form + Function, published by the architectural firm, W. V. Coscolluela & Associates is about the projects of the firm. Similarly, Planning & Design: Palafox Associates, The First 20 Years is a 308-page book that illustrates and documents 200 projects of the firm that embody the company’s vision of the future of urbanization. While some of these works might be taken to task for being marketing tools for a company, nonetheless, they give data and information that can be used for more analytical, systematic, and critical works, thus expanding and deepening the appreciation and understanding of Philippine architecture.  Written by René B. Javellana, with additional notes from Regalado Trota Jose

text:
Architectural schools are formal institutions of learning, where courses in the arts and sciences of building structures are taught to students.

The builders of indigenous houses were not trained in schools. They learned the skills of gathering materials like bamboo, reeds, nipa, cogon, wood, and vines, and of building houses from these materials from their elders or from the masters in their communities. Specialized skills like that of carving the okir or ukkil was learned by apprentices from master carvers. The building of the house itself was done through a system of cooperation, where the owner took care of the meals and other needs of the builders during the construction period.

 

There was no school of architecture in the Philippines during the Spanish regime. There was, however, the Escuela Practica y Profesional de Artes y Oficios de Manila, founded by the Spanish government in 1890, which granted the title maestro de obras or master builder. One of its first graduates was Arcadio Arellano.

The Liceo de Manila, a private institution founded in 1900 and headed by Leon Ma. Guerrero, offered an academic course for maestros de obras. In 1902, the Academia de Arquitectura y Agrimensura de Filipinas, a professional organization for architecture, civil engineering, and surveying was founded. It was later called the Academia de Ingenieria, Arquitectura y Agrimensura de Filipinas. In 1904, the Academia established the Escuela de Ingenieria y Arquitectura, which offered a five-year course in civil engineering and architecture. It was attached to the Liceo, and its faculty included members of the Academia. It closed after one year. In 1908, it was reopened, this time offering a three-year course for architecture, civil engineering, and electrical engineering. It ceased to operate in 1912.

During the first decades of the 20th century, young Filipinos went to the United States (US) to study architecture. The first US-trained Filipino architects included Carlos Barreto, Tomas Mapua, Juan Arellano, and Antonio Toledo.

 

In 1925, Mapua founded the Mapua Institute of Technology, a night school for working students, which offered, aside from engineering, a four-year course leading to the degree of Bachelor of Science in Architecture. In 1930, the University of Santo Tomas (UST) opened its own School of Fine Arts and Architecture. Adamson University opened its School of Architecture in 1941. In the same year, the Philippine College of Design was founded by Juan Nakpil, Andres Luna de San Pedro, Juan Arellano, Fernando Ocampo, Victorio Edades, Pablo Antonio, Angel Nakpil, and Gines Rivera. It did not survive World War II.

The Cebu Institute of Technology opened its own School of Architecture in 1946. This was the first Philippine school of architecture outside Manila. In 1947, the National University established its own architecture degree program. In 1949, the first school of architecture in Mindanao was opened by the Mindanao Colleges in Davao City, but it closed in 1953.

Subsequently, schools of architecture were opened by the following institutions: Far Eastern Air Transport Inc or FEATI in 1952; University of San Carlos in Cebu City in 1953; Far Eastern University and Manuel L. Quezon University in 1954; Francisco Colleges in 1955; the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1956; the University of San Agustin in Iloilo City in 1960; Saint Louis University in Baguio City in 1962; and the University of Mindanao in Davao City in 1970.

In the 1990s, there were 40 schools of architecture throughout the country, 15 of which were in the National Capital Region (NCR). The number has been growing as new schools have been offering more architecture courses. To date, 67 has been given as the number of schools in the Philippines, of which 16 are in NCR. Of the 67, 44 are accredited educational institutions.

 

In Luzon, these institutions are: Divine Word College of Laoag in Ilocos Norte; Isabela State University in Ilagan, Isabela; University of the Cordilleras in Baguio City, Benguet; University of Luzon in Dagupan City, Pangasinan; Don Honorio Ventura Technological State University in Bacolor, Pampanga; Cavite State University in Indang, Cavite; Holy Angel University in Angeles City, Pampanga; Don Bosco Technical College in Mandaluyong City; Divine Word College of Calapan in Oriental Mindoro; and University of Nueva Caceres in Naga, Camarines Sur. In the Visayas are these: West Visayas College of Science and Technology and University of San Agustin, both in Iloilo City, Iloilo; La Consolacion College Bacolod in Negros Occidental; Foundation University and Silliman University, both in Dumaguete City, Negros Oriental; and University of Bohol in Tagbilaran City. In Mindanao are University of Science and Technology of Southern Philippines in Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental; La Salle University in Ozamis City, Misamis Occidental; Surigao State College of Technology in Surigao City, Surigao; Caraga State University in Cabadbaran City, Agusan del Norte; and Notre Dame of Dadiangas University in General Santos City, South Cotabato.

Since its foundation in 1956, the UP College of Architecture has offered a five-year bachelor’s course, which all other schools followed starting in 1967. During the five-year course, a student receives a certificate of draftsmanship at the end of the second year, and a certificate for construction supervision at the end of the third year. The architecture curriculum includes architectural design, building technology, utilities, landscape architecture, site planning, urban and regional planning, housing, history of architecture, theory of architectural design, and professional practice, as well as drawing, color rendering, drafting, perspective drawing, and presentation techniques. Mathematics and science subjects include algebra, trigonometry, analytic geometry, differential calculus, integral calculus, physics, earth and life sciences, and architectural structures, focusing on timber, concrete, and steel. UP now offers master’s degrees in architecture and tropical landscape architecture. Likewise, UST offers a graduate course for the degree of master of science in architecture.

Aside from university degrees, there are institutions that provide training and apprenticeship. Escuela Taller de Filipinas is not so much an architectural school but a school that trains students in skills related to heritage conservation. Established internationally in 1985, the Escuela Taller opened a school in Intramuros in 2009. As the first Escuela Taller in Asia, the school trained Filipino youth in skills such as wood and stone carving, carpentry, and decorative painting. The curriculum also includes courses in electricity, plumbing, and related fields. Students also attend workshops and lectures on architectural design and history. They complement the work of architects involved in restoration.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III and updated by René B. Javellana
